authors: ['Miles Dilworth', 'Miles Dilworth Money Mail Reporter For The Daily Mail']
text:
More than 17,000 pensioners were forced to sell their homes to pay for social care last year, research by Money Mail reveals.

The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis.

The calculations reveal the scale of the emergency, showing that the numbers forced to sell their hard-won homes have soared 45 per cent since 2000.

The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis [File photo]

Last night campaigners called for urgent action and demanded a ‘national fund’ to pay for social care.

Morgan Vine, of charity Independent Age, said: ‘The pandemic is not a reason not to act – it is the reason why action has never been more vital.’

On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’.

On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’. But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility

But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility.

The cost of residential care has risen dramatically and now stands at more than £33,000 a year.

Anyone with more than £23,250 in funds, including their house value, is denied state help, leaving thousands having to sell their homes to pay soaring care bills.

The Daily Mail has campaigned to end this injustice for the families of those with dementia as well as other patients.

MoneyMail’s calculations, verified by Independent Age, are based on Department of Health data indicating that 30 per cent of those who pay for their residential care have to sell their homes.

The total was produced by comparing the numbers of self-funders in care provided by analysts Laing Buisson.

The research assumes the average stay is two-and-a-half years, as concluded in a study by the Personal Social Services Research Unit and Bupa.

It means around 350,000 elderly people are estimated to have sold their homes to pay for residential care since 1999.

Caroline Abrahams, director at charity Age UK, said: ‘When the threat from coronavirus finally recedes, Age UK will certainly be holding the Government to account on its promise to fix social care. The obvious solution is for us all to pay into a national fund, like we do with the NHS.’

She added: ‘Most people dread the idea of having to sell the family home to pay their care bills and the fact that this is the reality for substantial numbers is very sad.’

Ms Vine, head of policy at Independent Age, said: ‘These latest figures are a timely reminder of the need to fix the funding crisis that has plagued the social care system for decades, long before Covid-19.

Our family house since 1935 at risk Lynne Holmes had hoped to honour one of her father Harry Garrod’s last wishes and pass their family home on to the next generation. The three-bedroom house in Beckenham, south London, has belonged to them since 1935. Mrs Holmes, 63, recalls tales of how it sheltered her father and grandparents during the Second World War. Her father, a former post office worker, died in November aged 92 and her mother Doris, 90, has dementia and is in a £1,100-a-week care home. But their savings have run dry and they do not qualify for state support, leaving Mrs Holmes and her two siblings facing the heartbreak of having to sell the house. ‘My dad had been in that home since he was eight,’ she said. ‘We’ve had five generations enjoy family gatherings there.’ Advertisement

‘When taking office, the Prime Minister promised to solve the crisis, including preventing people from having to sell their homes to pay for care.

‘Although he couldn’t have predicted the challenges we now face, we can all predict the long-term consequences of failing to keep his promise.’

Liz Kendall, Labour’s social care spokesman, said: ‘The Prime Minister said, on the steps to Downing Street, that he has a plan to fix the crisis in social care and that no one should have to sell their homes to pay for their care.

‘Yet we have seen neither sight nor sound of any long-term plan for reform.

‘This must be an absolute top priority for the Government. People who have worked hard and saved all their life have seen their savings wiped out.’

A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: ‘We have committed to end the injustice that some people have to sell their homes to finance care whilst others don’t. We know there is a need for a long-term solution and are looking at proposals.’

            <h2>17,000 elderly people were forced to sell home to pay for care costs in just one year, figures reveal</h2><ul class="mol-bullets-with-font"><li class="class"><b>More than 300 elderly residents a week are having to sell homes to pay for care</b></li><li class="class"><strong>The numbers forced to sell their homes have soared 45 per cent since 2000 </strong></li><li class="class"><strong>Campaigners called for urgent action and demanded a ‘national fund’ for care </strong></li></ul><p class="author-section byline-plain">By <a href="/home/search.html?s=&authornamef=Miles+Dilworth+Money+Mail+Reporter+For+The+Daily+Mail" class="author" rel="nofollow">Miles Dilworth Money Mail Reporter For The Daily Mail</a> </p><p class="byline-section"><span class="article-timestamp article-timestamp-published"> <span class="article-timestamp-label">Published:</span> <time datetime="2020-10-05T00:53:15+0100"> 00:53 BST, 5 October 2020 </time> </span> | <span class="article-timestamp article-timestamp-updated"> <span class="article-timestamp-label">Updated:</span> <time datetime="2020-10-05T12:29:18+0100"> 12:29 BST, 5 October 2020 </time> </span> </p><p></p><div data-preferred-shared-network-enabled="" id="articleIconLinksContainer"> <ul> 
             
                
                    <li class="share-facebook-long"></li>
                    <li class="share-twitter"></li>
                
         <li class="share-pinterest"></li> <li class="share-flipboard"> <a class="js-tl" rel="" href=""></a> </li> <li class="share-fbmessenger"> <a class="js-tl" rel="" href=""></a> </li> <li class="share-email"> <a rel="nofollow noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" href="mailto:?subject=Read this: 17,000 elderly people were forced to sell home to pay for care costs in just one year, figures reveal &body=17%2C000%20elderly%20people%20were%20forced%20to%20sell%20home%20to%20pay%20for%20care%20costs%20in%20just%20one%20year%2C%20figures%20reveal%C2%A0%0A%0AMore%20than%2017%2C000%20pensioners%20were%20forced%20to%20sell%20their%20homes%20to%20pay%20for%20social%20care%20last%20year%2C%20research%20by%20Money%20Mail%20reveals.%0A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8804883%2F17-000-elderly-people-forced-sell-home-pay-care-costs-just-one-year.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top%0A%0A%0AMost%20Read%20Articles%3A%0A%0APlan%20for%20%27harsher%20three-tier%20lockdowns%27%3A%20Leaked%20document%20reveals%20possible%20pub%20closures%20and%20ban%20on%20ALL%20social%20contact%20outside%20your%20household%20under%20proposed%20red%2C%20amber%2C%20green%20%27traffic-light%27%20system%C2%A0%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8804313%2FLeaked-document-reveals-proposed-three-tier-traffic-light-tackle-coronavirus.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0APictured%3A%20British%20man%20who%20died%20after%20travelling%20to%20Turkey%20for%20teeth%20whitening%20treatment%20with%20two%20friends%20who%20are%20critically%20ill%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8805657%2FNorthern-Ireland-man-33-dies-Turkey-travelling-dental-work-two-friends-hospital.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0A%27Sweets%27%20that%20put%2013%20teenage%20girls%20in%20hospital%20contained%20CANNABIS%3A%20Police%20open%20probe%20into%20incident%20that%20sparked%20panic%20at%20North%20London%20Catholic%20school%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8806671%2FParamedics-rush-13-teenage-children-hospital-incident-north-London-school.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0A"> <span class="wai">e-mail</span> </a> </li> <li data-anchor="tl" data-twitter-status=" https://mol.im/a/8804883 via @MailOnline" data-formatted-headline="17,000 people were forced to sell home to pay for care in a year" data-hide-email="true" data-article-id="8804883" data-article-channel-follow-button="MailOnline" data-is-channel="false" id="shareLinkTop" class="share-icons" data-placement="top" data-url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8804883/17-000-elderly-people-forced-sell-home-pay-care-costs-just-one-year.html"> <a class="js-sl share-link email_share_article-top" href="#socialLinks"></a> </li> </ul> <div class="share-count"> <b>121</b> <span>shares</span> </div> <a class="comments-count home" href="/news/article-8804883/17-000-elderly-people-forced-sell-home-pay-care-costs-just-one-year.html#comments"> <span></span> <p class="count-number"> 415</p> <p class="count-text">View <br /> comments</p> </a> </div> <!-- ad: https://mads.dailymail.co.uk/v6/in/news/none/article/other/para_top.html --> <p></p><div itemprop="articleBody"><p class="mol-para-with-font">More than 17,000 pensioners were forced to sell their homes to pay for social care last year, research by Money Mail reveals.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite <a style="font-weight: bold;" href="/news/boris_johnson/index.html" id="mol-c4af74f0-069c-11eb-a0ad-89a08d08cab3">Boris Johnson</a>’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The calculations reveal the scale of the emergency, showing that the numbers forced to sell their hard-won homes have soared 45 per cent since 2000.</p><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-26aee27c47ca1111" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2019/07/23/01/15458910-7198767-Thousands_of_people_with_dementia_are_being_denied_vital_care_be-a-1_1563843441099.jpg" height="422" width="633" alt="The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis [File photo]" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-26aee27c47ca1111" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2019/07/23/01/15458910-7198767-Thousands_of_people_with_dementia_are_being_denied_vital_care_be-a-1_1563843441099.jpg" height="422" width="633" alt="The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis [File photo]" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption"> The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis [File photo]</p></div><p class="mol-para-with-font">Last night campaigners called for urgent action and demanded a ‘national fund’ to pay for social care.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Morgan Vine, of charity Independent Age, said: ‘The pandemic is not a reason not to act – it is the reason why action has never been more vital.’</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’.</p><div class="mol-img-group floatRHS" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-d121193b182f0394" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33979158-0-On_his_first_day_in_No_10_in_July_2019_Mr_Johnson_vowed_to_make_-m-67_1601855096981.jpg" height="430" width="306" alt="On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’. But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-d121193b182f0394" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33979158-0-On_his_first_day_in_No_10_in_July_2019_Mr_Johnson_vowed_to_make_-m-67_1601855096981.jpg" height="430" width="306" alt="On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’. But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">On his first day in No 10 in July 2019, Mr Johnson vowed to make social care a priority and end the crisis ‘once and for all’. But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility</p></div><p class="mol-para-with-font">But he has since admitted action would be delayed and the coronavirus crisis has made immediate reform a remote possibility.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The cost of residential care has risen dramatically and now stands at more than £33,000 a year.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Anyone with more than £23,250 in funds, including their house value, is denied state help, leaving thousands having to sell their homes to pay soaring care bills.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The Daily Mail has campaigned to end this injustice for the families of those with dementia as well as other patients.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">MoneyMail’s calculations, verified by Independent Age, are based on Department of Health data indicating that 30 per cent of those who pay for their residential care have to sell their homes.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The total was produced by comparing the numbers of self-funders in care provided by analysts Laing Buisson.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The research assumes the average stay is two-and-a-half years, as concluded in a study by the Personal Social Services Research Unit and Bupa.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">It means around 350,000 elderly people are estimated to have sold their homes to pay for residential care since 1999.</p><div><div data-track-module="am-related_carousel^related_carousel" data-track-selector=".rotator-panels a:not([class*=external])" data-dm-rotator-rotate="false" data-track-pos="static" data-preferred-shared-network-enabled="" data-dm-rotator-auto-init="" id="p-22" class="related-carousel with-fb-or-tw                 <div class="fb">
                  <h2>Share this article</h2>
                  <div class="share"><span class="wai">Share</span></div>

   </div> </div><p class="mol-para-with-font">Caroline Abrahams, director at charity Age UK, said: ‘When the threat from coronavirus finally recedes, Age UK will certainly be holding the Government to account on its promise to fix social care. The obvious solution is for us all to pay into a national fund, like we do with the NHS.’</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">She added: ‘Most people dread the idea of having to sell the family home to pay their care bills and the fact that this is the reality for substantial numbers is very sad.’</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Ms Vine, head of policy at Independent Age, said: ‘These latest figures are a timely reminder of the need to fix the funding crisis that has plagued the social care system for decades, long before Covid-19.</p><div class="art-ins mol-factbox news" data-version="2" id="mol-a1b73200-069a-11eb-a0ad-89a08d08cab3" data-permabox-url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8804883/17-000-elderly-people-forced-sell-home-pay-care-costs-just-one-year.html"> <h3 class="mol-factbox-title">Our family house since 1935 at risk</h3> <div class="ins cleared mol-factbox-body"> <p class="mol-para-with-font">Lynne Holmes had hoped to honour one of her father Harry Garrod’s last wishes and pass their family home on to the next generation.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The three-bedroom house in Beckenham, south London, has belonged to them since 1935. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Mrs Holmes, 63, recalls tales of how it sheltered her father and grandparents during the Second World War.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Her father, a former post office worker, died in November aged 92 and her mother Doris, 90, has dementia and is in a £1,100-a-week care home.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">But their savings have run dry and they do not qualify for state support, leaving Mrs Holmes and her two siblings facing the heartbreak of having to sell the house.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">‘My dad had been in that home since he was eight,’ she said. ‘We’ve had five generations enjoy family gatherings there.’</p> </div><div data-swipe-article="false">
<div class="adHolder mpu" id="mpu_factbox_1"><!- - ad: https://mads.dailymail.co.uk/v6/in/news/none/article/other/mpu_factbox.html - -><script>adverts.addToArray({"pos":"mpu_factbox"})</script><span class="mol-ads-label-container"><span class="mol-ads-label">Advertisement</span></span>
</div>
</div> </div><p class="mol-para-with-font">‘When taking office, the Prime Minister promised to solve the crisis, including preventing people from having to sell their homes to pay for care.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">‘Although he couldn’t have predicted the challenges we now face, we can all predict the long-term consequences of failing to keep his promise.’</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Liz Kendall, Labour’s social care spokesman, said: ‘The Prime Minister said, on the steps to Downing Street, that he has a plan to fix the crisis in social care and that no one should have to sell their homes to pay for their care.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">‘Yet we have seen neither sight nor sound of any long-term plan for reform.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">‘This must be an absolute top priority for the Government. People who have worked hard and saved all their life have seen their savings wiped out.’</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: ‘We have committed to end the injustice that some people have to sell their homes to finance care whilst others don’t. We know there is a need for a long-term solution and are looking at proposals.’</p></div>

summary:
More than 17,000 pensioners were forced to sell their homes to pay for social care last year, research by Money Mail reveals.
The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis.
The shocking figure means that 330 elderly residents each week are taking the desperate step despite Boris Johnson’s promise to fix the social care funding crisis [File photo]Last night campaigners called for urgent action and demanded a ‘national fund’ to pay for social care.
Anyone with more than £23,250 in funds, including their house value, is denied state help, leaving thousands having to sell their homes to pay soaring care bills.
It means around 350,000 elderly people are estimated to have sold their homes to pay for residential care since 1999.
title: 17,000 elderly people were forced to sell home to pay for care costs in just one year

authors: ['Charlie Moore', 'Political Reporter', 'Stephen Johnson', 'Economics Reporter For Daily Mail Australia']
text:
Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts.

With the country in recession for the first time in almost three decades, income tax cuts originally earmarked for July 2022 are set to be backdated to July 2020.

The stage-two cuts will benefit middle-to-high income earners, giving those earning $100,000 an extra $1,665 each year and those earning $120,000 an extra $2,565.

Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts. Pictured: A tradeswoman at work

This is how much you will get back after stage two tax cuts compared with the 2017-18 financial year. Most of these changes are already in place after stage one tax cuts. The difference this time is that Aussies earning more than $100,000 will get $1,665 back and those on more than $120,000 will get $2,565 back. Under current tax rules those on $120,000 only get back $315

They build on stage-one cuts already introduced which give those earning $50,000 to $80,000 an extra $1,080.

Backdating the stage-two cuts, which raise the threshold for the 37 per cent tax bracket from $90,000 to $120,000, means they will kick in as soon as they are passed by parliament.

Those who benefit will have to pay less tax each month and the government hopes this will help drive spending and boost the economy after it was hammered by coronavirus.

Another stage of tax cuts, which helps high earners and is due to take effect in 2024, is likely to be brought forward.

The third stage of tax cuts abolishes the 37 per cent tax bracket and creates a 30 per cent tax bracket for those earning $45,001 and $200,000.

The slashing of tax brackets, from five to four for the first time since 1984, will see those at the top end on $200,000 receive a tax cut of $11,640 compared with the 2017-18 financial year.

Sources told the AFR that stage two and stage three tax cuts will be presented to parliament in a single bill.

Labor supports stage two but not stage three, setting up a potential battle in the senate where the government lacks a majority.

Critics say high earners will save their extra cash instead of spend it, but Treasurer Josh Frydenberg insisted spending levels will increase as coronavirus restrictions are lifted.

He told the Nine Network on Sunday: 'Putting more money into people's pockets means more economic activity and means more jobs.

'Once those restrictions are eased and people are getting back to work and life is coming back to a Covid-safe normal, then more money would be spent and the savings ratio would go down.'

The third stage of the federal government's tax cuts was designed to give generous relief to those on six-figure salaries from July 2024. This could be accelerated in Tuesday's budget. This table shows how much you will get back after stage three compared with 2017-18

Scott Morrison (pictured in his office in Canberra) has said Tuesday's budget is the most important since World War Two

Mr Frydenberg will announce his budget in a speech to parliament at 7.30pm on Tuesday.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has described it as the 'most important budget since the Second World War.'

The budget is normally announced in May, but the government pushed it back to better analyse the impact of the pandemic and prepare a more thorough response.

In September ministers learned that in the three months until 30 June, the economy shrank by seven per cent, the biggest contraction since quarterly records began in 1959.

On an annual basis the economy took a 6.3 per cent hit, the worst figure since the depths of the Great Depression when it shrank by about 10 per cent, and a greater contraction than after the Second World War in 1945 when growth tumbled by 5.1 per cent as troops returned home.

Not only is the government dealing with a fragile economy, but also a rapidly growing mountain of public debt after spending billions of dollars on coronavirus policies.

Measures to soften the impact of restrictions such as the boosted JobSeeker allowance and the JobKeeper payment have economists predicting a budget shortfall of more than $200billion this year.

This graph shows how the economy has been hammered by coronavirus compared with previous downturns

This graph shows how employment nosedived due to lockdowns. But more than 700,000 jobs have come back since June as restrictions were lifted

<div class="articleWide cleared">

      <div id="js-article-text" class="article-text wide  heading-tag-switch">
            <h2>Cash splash! How Budget tax cuts will be backdated to July this year giving Aussies tax relief of up to $2,565 and more money in their pay packet each month</h2><ul class="mol-bullets-with-font"><li class="class"><strong>Stage two tax cuts would give those earning $100,000 an extra $1,665 each year</strong></li><li class="class"><strong>Those earning $120,000 will get an extra $2,565 under the government's plan </strong></li><li class="class"><strong>The changes were originally due in 2022 but will be backdated to July 2020 </strong></li><li class="class"><strong>This means they will take effect instantly, meaning Aussies pay less each month </strong></li></ul><p class="author-section byline-plain">By <a href="/home/search.html?s=&authornamef=Charlie+Moore,+Political+Reporter" class="author" rel="nofollow">Charlie Moore, Political Reporter</a> and <a href="/home/search.html?s=&authornamef=Stephen+Johnson,+Economics+Reporter+For+Daily+Mail+Australia" class="author" rel="nofollow">Stephen Johnson, Economics Reporter For Daily Mail Australia</a> </p><p class="byline-section"><span class="article-timestamp article-timestamp-published"> <span class="article-timestamp-label">Published:</span> <time datetime="2020-10-05T00:46:13+0100"> 00:46 BST, 5 October 2020 </time> </span> | <span class="article-timestamp article-timestamp-updated"> <span class="article-timestamp-label">Updated:</span> <time datetime="2020-10-05T01:06:31+0100"> 01:06 BST, 5 October 2020 </time> </span> </p><p></p><div data-preferred-shared-network-enabled="" id="articleIconLinksContainer"> <ul> 
             
                
                    <li class="share-facebook-long"></li>
                    <li class="share-twitter"></li>
                
         <li class="share-pinterest"></li> <li class="share-flipboard"> <a class="js-tl" rel="" href=""></a> </li> <li class="share-fbmessenger"> <a class="js-tl" rel="" href=""></a> </li> <li class="share-email"> <a rel="nofollow noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" href="mailto:?subject=Read this: Cash splash! How Budget tax cuts will be backdated to July this year giving Aussies tax relief of up to $2,565 and more money in their pay packet each month&body=Cash%20splash%21%20How%20Budget%20tax%20cuts%20will%20be%20backdated%20to%20July%20this%20year%20giving%20Aussies%20tax%20relief%20of%20up%20to%20%242%2C565%20and%20more%20money%20in%20their%20pay%20packet%20each%20month%0A%0AWith%20the%20country%20in%20recession%20for%20the%20first%20time%20in%20almost%20three%20decades%2C%20income%20tax%20cuts%20originally%20earmarked%20for%20July%202022%20are%20set%20to%20be%20backdated%20to%20July%202020.%0A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8804597%2FCash-splash-Budget-tax-cuts-backdated-July-year.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top%0A%0A%0AMost%20Read%20Articles%3A%0A%0APlan%20for%20%27harsher%20three-tier%20lockdowns%27%3A%20Leaked%20document%20reveals%20possible%20pub%20closures%20and%20ban%20on%20ALL%20social%20contact%20outside%20your%20household%20under%20proposed%20red%2C%20amber%2C%20green%20%27traffic-light%27%20system%C2%A0%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8804313%2FLeaked-document-reveals-proposed-three-tier-traffic-light-tackle-coronavirus.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0APictured%3A%20British%20man%20who%20died%20after%20travelling%20to%20Turkey%20for%20teeth%20whitening%20treatment%20with%20two%20friends%20who%20are%20critically%20ill%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8805657%2FNorthern-Ireland-man-33-dies-Turkey-travelling-dental-work-two-friends-hospital.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0A%27Sweets%27%20that%20put%2013%20teenage%20girls%20in%20hospital%20contained%20CANNABIS%3A%20Police%20open%20probe%20into%20incident%20that%20sparked%20panic%20at%20North%20London%20Catholic%20school%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-8806671%2FParamedics-rush-13-teenage-children-hospital-incident-north-London-school.html%3Fito%3Demail_share_article-top_most-read-articles%0A%0A"> <span class="wai">e-mail</span> </a> </li> <li data-anchor="tl" data-twitter-status=" https://mol.im/a/8804597 via @MailOnline" data-formatted-headline="Cash splash! How Budget tax cuts will be backdated to July this year" data-hide-email="true" data-article-id="8804597" data-article-channel-follow-button="MailOnline" data-is-channel="false" id="shareLinkTop" class="share-icons" data-placement="top" data-url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8804597/Cash-splash-Budget-tax-cuts-backdated-July-year.html"> <a class="js-sl share-link email_share_article-top" href="#socialLinks"></a> </li> </ul> <div class="share-count"> <b>144</b> <span>shares</span> </div> <a class="comments-count home" href="/news/article-8804597/Cash-splash-Budget-tax-cuts-backdated-July-year.html#comments"> <span></span> <p class="count-number"> 11</p> <p class="count-text">View <br /> comments</p> </a> </div> <!-- ad: https://mads.dailymail.co.uk/v6/in/news/none/article/other/para_top.html --> <p></p><div itemprop="articleBody"><p class="mol-para-with-font">Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">With the country in recession for the first time in almost three decades, income tax cuts originally earmarked for July 2022 are set to be backdated to July 2020.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The stage-two cuts will benefit middle-to-high income earners, giving those earning $100,000 an extra $1,665 each year and those earning $120,000 an extra $2,565.</p><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-4d31dab8833687e5" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33981300-8804597-image-m-5_1601852834438.jpg" height="542" width="634" alt="Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts. Pictured: A tradeswoman at work" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-4d31dab8833687e5" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33981300-8804597-image-m-5_1601852834438.jpg" height="542" width="634" alt="Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts. Pictured: A tradeswoman at work" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts. Pictured: A tradeswoman at work</p></div><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-e149d5d7a5d584b1" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/01/06/33844488-8792817-image-a-29_1601531471012.jpg" height="621" width="634" alt="This is how much you will get back after stage two tax cuts compared with the 2017-18 financial year. Most of these changes are already in place after stage one tax cuts. The difference this time is that  Aussies earning more than $100,000 will get $1,665 back and those on more than $120,000 will get $2,565 back. Under current tax rules those on $120,000 only get back $315" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-e149d5d7a5d584b1" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/01/06/33844488-8792817-image-a-29_1601531471012.jpg" height="621" width="634" alt="This is how much you will get back after stage two tax cuts compared with the 2017-18 financial year. Most of these changes are already in place after stage one tax cuts. The difference this time is that  Aussies earning more than $100,000 will get $1,665 back and those on more than $120,000 will get $2,565 back. Under current tax rules those on $120,000 only get back $315" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">This is how much you will get back after stage two tax cuts compared with the 2017-18 financial year. Most of these changes are already in place after stage one tax cuts. The difference this time is that  Aussies earning more than $100,000 will get $1,665 back and those on more than $120,000 will get $2,565 back. Under current tax rules those on $120,000 only get back $315</p></div><p class="mol-para-with-font">They build on stage-one cuts already introduced which give those earning $50,000 to $80,000 an extra $1,080.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Backdating the stage-two cuts, which raise the threshold for the 37 per cent tax bracket from $90,000 to $120,000, means they will kick in as soon as they are passed by parliament.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Those who benefit will have to pay less tax each month and the government hopes this will help drive spending and boost the economy after it was hammered by coronavirus. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Another stage of tax cuts, which helps high earners and is due to take effect in 2024, is likely to be brought forward. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The third stage of tax cuts abolishes the 37 per cent tax bracket and creates a 30 per cent tax bracket for those earning $45,001 and $200,000. </p><div><div data-track-module="am-related_carousel^related_carousel" data-track-selector=".rotator-panels a:not([class*=external])" data-dm-rotator-rotate="false" data-track-pos="static" data-preferred-shared-network-enabled="" data-dm-rotator-auto-init="" id="p-22" class="related-carousel with-fb-or-tw news half" data-dm-rotator-active-class="active" data-dm-rotator-page-count="1.0" data-dm-social-article-auto-init="" data-dm-rotator-page-size="1"> <div class="rotator bdrcc"> <div class="rotator-title"> <h2>RELATED ARTICLES</h2> <ul class="rotator-pages link-xocc"> <li src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/02/07/33892096-0-image-m-25_1601618723327.jpg" width="62" height="60" /> <span>'The most important budget since World War Two': How Scott...</span> </a> <a href="/news/article-8803635/The-7-5BILLION-infrastructure-cash-splash-new-roads-rail-projects.html"> <img src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/04/16/33970112-0-image-m-63_1601825216279.jpg"                 <div class="fb">
                  <h2>Share this article</h2>
                  <div class="share"><span class="wai">Share</span></div>
                </div>
            
   </div> </div><p class="mol-para-with-font">The slashing of tax brackets, from five to four for the first time since 1984, will see those at the top end on $200,000 receive a tax cut of $11,640 compared with the 2017-18 financial year.   </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Sources told the <a style="font-weight: bold;" class="class" rel="nofollow noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" href="https://www.afr.com/politics/federal/revealed-budget-tax-cuts-to-be-backdated-20201004-p561t2">AFR</a> that stage two and stage three tax cuts will be presented to parliament in a single bill. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Labor supports stage two but not stage three, setting up a potential battle in the senate where the government lacks a majority.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Critics say high earners will save their extra cash instead of spend it, but Treasurer Josh Frydenberg insisted spending levels will increase as coronavirus restrictions are lifted. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">He told the Nine Network on Sunday: 'Putting more money into people's pockets means more economic activity and means more jobs. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">'Once those restrictions are eased and people are getting back to work and life is coming back to a Covid-safe normal, then more money would be spent and the savings ratio would go down.'</p><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-c17b1337231587c9" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/01/06/33842398-8792817-image-a-21_1601530834316.jpg" height="897" width="634" alt="The third stage of the federal government's tax cuts was designed to give generous relief to those on six-figure salaries from July 2024. This could be accelerated in Tuesday's budget. This table shows how much you will get back after stage three compared with 2017-18" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-c17b1337231587c9" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/01/06/33842398-8792817-image-a-21_1601530834316.jpg" height="897" width="634" alt="The third stage of the federal government's tax cuts was designed to give generous relief to those on six-figure salaries from July 2024. This could be accelerated in Tuesday's budget. This table shows how much you will get back after stage three compared with 2017-18" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">The third stage of the federal government's tax cuts was designed to give generous relief to those on six-figure salaries from July 2024. This could be accelerated in Tuesday's budget. This table shows how much you will get back after stage three compared with 2017-18</p></div><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-11957cd56071c1bc" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33892096-8804597-Scott_Morrison_pictured_in_his_office_in_Canberra_has_said_Tuesd-a-1_1601852796523.jpg" height="411" width="630" alt="Scott Morrison (pictured in his office in Canberra) has said Tuesday's budget is the most important since World War Two" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-11957cd56071c1bc" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/05/00/33892096-8804597-Scott_Morrison_pictured_in_his_office_in_Canberra_has_said_Tuesd-a-1_1601852796523.jpg" height="411" width="630" alt="Scott Morrison (pictured in his office in Canberra) has said Tuesday's budget is the most important since World War Two" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">Scott Morrison (pictured in his office in Canberra) has said Tuesday's budget is the most important since World War Two</p></div><p class="mol-para-with-font">Mr Frydenberg will announce his budget in a speech to parliament at 7.30pm on Tuesday. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Prime Minister Scott Morrison has described it as the 'most important budget since the Second World War.'</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The budget is normally announced in May, but the government pushed it back to better analyse the impact of the pandemic and prepare a more thorough response.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">In September ministers learned that in the three months until 30 June, the economy shrank by seven per cent, the biggest contraction since quarterly records began in 1959. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">On an annual basis the economy took a 6.3 per cent hit, the worst figure since the depths of the Great Depression when it shrank by about 10 per cent, and a greater contraction than <span style="font-size: 16px;">after the Second World War in 1945 when growth tumbled by 5.1 per cent as troops returned home. </span></p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Not only is the government dealing with a fragile economy, but also a rapidly growing mountain of public debt after spending billions of dollars on coronavirus policies. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Measures to soften the impact of restrictions such as the boosted JobSeeker allowance and the JobKeeper payment have economists predicting a budget shortfall of more than $200billion this year.   </p><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-a2658a7b25f05b4c" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/02/07/33892070-8797185-image-a-35_1601621959472.jpg" height="367" width="634" alt="This graph shows how the economy has been hammered by coronavirus compared with previous downturns" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-a2658a7b25f05b4c" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/02/07/33892070-8797185-image-a-35_1601621959472.jpg" height="367" width="634" alt="This graph shows how the economy has been hammered by coronavirus compared with previous downturns" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">This graph shows how the economy has been hammered by coronavirus compared with previous downturns</p></div><div class="artSplitter mol-img-group" style="style"> <div class="mol-img"> <div class="image-wrap"> <img id="i-23a73da05aa2b8d4" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/02/07/33892072-8797185-image-a-34_1601621761269.jpg" height="367" width="634" alt="This graph shows how employment nosedived due to lockdowns. But more than 700,000 jobs have come back since June as restrictions were lifted" class="blkBorder img-share" style="max-width:100%" /> </div> <noscript> <img id="i-23a73da05aa2b8d4" src="https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2020/10/02/07/33892072-8797185-image-a-34_1601621761269.jpg" height="367" width="634" alt="This graph shows how employment nosedived due to lockdowns. But more than 700,000 jobs have come back since June as restrictions were lifted" class="blkBorder img-share" /> </noscript> </div> <p class="imageCaption">This graph shows how employment nosedived due to lockdowns. But more than 700,000 jobs have come back since June as restrictions were lifted</p></div><div class="art-ins mol-factbox news" data-version="2" id="mol-8f904dd0-0688-11eb-bca2-11a9e274e84c" data-permabox-url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8804597/Cash-splash-Budget-tax-cuts-backdated-July-year.html"> <h3 class="mol-factbox-title">Australia's three stages of tax cuts</h3> <div class="ins cleared mol-factbox-body"> <p class="mol-para-with-font">Tax cuts of $255 for those earning between $18,200 and $37,000 were legislated in July 2019.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Those earning $48,000 to $90,000 saw their tax cuts double from $530 to $1,080.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The government's tax cuts package, announced in the April 2019 pre-election Budget, had three stages.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font"><span class="mol-style-bold">Stage one</span> increased the threshold for the 32.5 per cent personal income tax bracket from $87,000 to $90,000, over four years until 2022.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font"><span class="mol-style-bold">Stage two</span>, from July 1, 2022, would increase the 19 per cent personal income tax bracket from $41,000 to $45,000. It also raises the 32.5 per cent personal income tax bracket from $90,000 to $120,000.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font"><span class="mol-style-bold">Stage three</span> would see the 37 per cent tax bracket abolished from July 1, 2024 and a new 30 per cent tax bracket created for all individuals earning between $45,001 and $200,000. The number of tax brackets would be slashed from five to four for the first time since 1984 </p> </div><div data-swipe-article="false">
<div class="adHolder mpu" id="mpu_factbox_1"><!- - ad: https://mads.dailymail.co.uk/v6/in/news/none/article/other/mpu_factbox.html - -><script>adverts.addToArray({"pos":"mpu_factbox"})</script><span class="mol-ads-label-container"><span class="mol-ads-label">Advertisement</span></span>
</div>
</div> </div></div>

summary:
With the country in recession for the first time in almost three decades, income tax cuts originally earmarked for July 2022 are set to be backdated to July 2020.
Millions of Australians will keep more of their money this year as the government plans to backdate tax cuts.
Pictured: A tradeswoman at workThis is how much you will get back after stage two tax cuts compared with the 2017-18 financial year.
The third stage of tax cuts abolishes the 37 per cent tax bracket and creates a 30 per cent tax bracket for those earning $45,001 and $200,000.
Sources told the AFR that stage two and stage three tax cuts will be presented to parliament in a single bill.
title: Cash splash! How Budget tax cuts will be backdated to July this year

text:
After surviving some of the bloodiest combat in Afghanistan, the men of the 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment stayed connected on social media for support at home as they dealt with the fallout of war.

It was a rough transition to civilian life. Many were disillusioned about why they fought; others struggled with post-traumatic stress. Suicide stalked their ranks. Those close online connections offered something the veterans' health care system did not: common ground, understanding, friends ready to talk.

But the connections that held strong through all those troubles have been frayed to breaking by the partisan rancor of 2020. The Facebook group the men once relied on for support is now clogged with divisive memes and partisan conspiracy theories, disputes over policing and protests, and, of course, strong views on the president.

The din has driven a growing number of members to log off in dismay. Many say they still want to support their fellow Marines but cannot stand the toxic political traffic.

Party strategists and analysts tend to treat veterans as a homogeneous voting bloc, conservative-leaning and focused mainly on defense and benefits issues. But veterans are increasingly diverse in their outlook and deeply divided over the election.

The explosive issues of a strange year and the unconventional presidency of Donald Trump have pried veterans apart, just as they have divided families at kitchen tables and friends in now-canceled softball leagues. Like many other Americans, veterans can find it hard even to agree to disagree when so many see November as a critical turning point.

Ruben Sevilla, a former lance corporal, who keeps in touch with a small group of friends from the battalion, in Oswego, Ill., Oct. 1, 2020. He said he has drifted away from the larger group in part because of the partisan bickering. Toxic rhetoric and political polarization are doing what nothing else could: driving apart ex-Marines who had one another’s backs through wars and the stresses of civilian life. (Taylor Glascock/The New York Times)

And those cracks are clear among the veterans of the 2/7. Many from the battalion have unfollowed longtime friends. Some have left the unit's online support group entirely.

"It hurts my soul to see all this childish drama," said Keith Branch, a former infantryman from the battalion. "Brothers that formed bonds in war, I see them becoming broken over childish arguments. I disconnect from it — I'm already dealing with post-traumatic stress. It hurts too much to look at it."

In 2015, veterans of the battalion's combat deployments had a suicide rate 14 times the national average, and Branch, who lives in Texas, helped to set up the rapid response network of volunteers who could race to the scene when a fellow battalion veteran was contemplating suicide. The group made several critical interventions to save lives.

Now, he said, members of the Facebook group are much less willing to open up amid the partisan hostility, and real discussion about the fallout of combat has grown rare.

"People are saying they are never going to talk to each other again," said Branch, who does not plan to vote this year. "I don't get it. We went to war to fight extremism. I don't understand why we can't find common ground."

Danny Kwan was one of many Marines who nearly killed himself after coming home. With the support of friends from the battalion, he graduated from college, interned for a congresswoman and became a firefighter. He has backed both Democrats and Republicans over the years. This year he plans to vote for Joe Biden, he said, primarily because he is wary of a second Trump term.

In 2016, exit polls showed that veterans backed Trump over Hillary Clinton by nearly 2 to 1. Veterans skew old and male and white, and so does the core of Trump's support.

As a candidate in 2016, Trump blasted the politicians and generals who had perpetuated the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and had ignored problems with veterans' health care, former Marine Alex McCoy said. "He picked the right enemies, he was yelling at the right people," McCoy said.

It is unclear now whether Trump will be able to muster as much support.

            }
            return false;

        function isPhone () {
          return /Android|webOS|iPhone|iPod|BlackBerry|BB|PlayBook|IEMobile|Windows Phone|Kindle|Silk|Opera Mini/i.test(navigator.userAgent)
        }

        if (isPhone() && location.hostname.indexOf('video') !== -1) { //If the user is on a phone and enters the site on a desktop video page, redirect to mobile
          var userAgent = navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase()

            var referrer = document.referrer

            if (referrer.indexOf('www.startribune.com') === -1 && referrer.indexOf('video.startribune.com') === -1 || referrer === '') { //Make sure the user isn't already browsing the desktop site on mobile, we don't want to force mobile in that case

            }

                    <script type="text/javascript">
            var overlayRes = "";

            function overlayInterstitial(string, leftPosition, creativeWidth, creativeHeight, topPosition, leftPositionButton, Buttonwidth, ButtonHeight) {
                if (leftPosition == "centeredpx") {  // set left position if centered
                    var dcw = 0;
                    if (!window.innerWidth)  //IE
                        if (!(document.documentElement.clientWidth == 0))dcw = document.documentElement.clientWidth;  //strict mode
                        else dcw = document.body.clientWidth;  //quirks mode
                    else dcw = window.innerWidth;  //w3c
                    leftPosition = (dcw - creativeWidth) / 2 + "px";
                    leftPositionButton = Number(creativeWidth) + Number((dcw - creativeWidth) / 2) - Number(Buttonwidth);
                    leftPositionButton = leftPositionButton + "px";
                }
                if (topPosition == "centeredpx") {  // set top position if centered
                    var dch = 0;
                    if (!window.innerWidth)  //IE
                        if (!(document.documentElement.clientWidth == 0)) dch = document.documentElement.clientHeight;  //strict mode
                        else dch = document.body.clientHeight;  //quirks mode
                    else dch = window.innerHeight;  //w3c
                    topPosition = (dch - creativeHeight) / 2 + "px";
                }

                var topPosNum = parseFloat(topPosition.replace('px', ''));
                var buttonTop = (topPosNum - ButtonHeight);
                if (buttonTop < 0) {
                    buttonTop = 0;
                }

                var res = string.replace(/\**BTOP/g, buttonTop + 'px');
                res = res.replace(/\**TOP/g, topPosition);
                res = res.replace(/\**BLEFT/g, leftPositionButton);
                res = res.replace(/\**LEFT/g, leftPosition);
                res += '<\/div>';

                window.overlayRes = res;

                $(document).ready(function () {
                    if (!isPhone() && !isWelcomeShowing()) {
                        jQuery( '<div>' ).attr( 'id', 'interstitial-overlay' ).html( window.overlayRes ).appendTo( jQuery( 'body' ) );
                    }
                });
            }

            function dclk_hide_overlay() {
                jQuery( '#interstitial-overlay').empty().css( 'display', 'none' );
            }
        </script>

<script>
  function addPhoto () {
    $('#welcome-screen-link').append('<img src="https://stmedia.stimg.co/08-1011668841___03FALL092320.pix.jpg?w=970" alt="Snapshots" title="Photo" id="welcome-photo-img">')
  }

  function isGoogleBot () {
    let botPattern = '(googlebot/|Googlebot-Mobile|Googlebot-Image)'
    let re = new RegExp(botPattern, 'i')

    return re.test(navigator.userAgent)
  }

  function AddWelcomeAd () {
    let windowW = $(window).width(),
      adHtml = '<IFRAME SRC="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/adi/N3175.132427STARTRIBUNEMEDIACOMP/B24704913.283714395;sz=320x50;ord=[timestamp];dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=?"     if (windowW > 1000) {
      adHtml = '<IFRAME SRC="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/adi/N3175.132427STARTRIBUNEMEDIACOMP/B24704913.283714395;sz=970x90;ord=[timestamp];dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=?" WIDTH=970 HEIGHT=90 MARGINWIDTH=0 MARGINHEIGHT=0 HSPACE=0 VSPACE=0 FRAMEBORDER=0 SCROLLING=no BORDERCOLOR='#000000'><SCRIPT language='JavaScript1.1' SRC="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/adj/N3175.132427STARTRIBUNEMEDIACOMP/B24704913.283714395;abr=!ie;sz=970x90;ord=[timestamp];dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=?"></SCRIPT></IFRAME>'
    } else if (windowW > 760) {
      adHtml = '<IFRAME SRC="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/adi/N3175.132427STARTRIBUNEMEDIACOMP/B24704913.283714395;sz=728x90;ord=[timestamp];dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=?" WIDTH=728 HEIGHT=90 MARGINWIDTH=0 MARGINHEIGHT=0 HSPACE=0 VSPACE=0 FRAMEBORDER=0 SCROLLING=no BORDERCOLOR='#000000'><SCRIPT language='JavaScript1.1' SRC="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/adj/N3175.132427STARTRIBUNEMEDIACOMP/B24704913.283714395;abr=!ie;sz=728x90;ord=[timestamp];dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=?"></SCRIPT></IFRAME>'
    }
    if (adHtml && adHtml.length > 0) {
      document.getElementById('div-gpt-ad-leaderboard-1').innerHTML = $('<textarea />').html(adHtml).text()
    }
  }

  function bindWelcome () {
    $(document).ready(function () {
      //fire Omniture event as the welcome screen appears, to log appearance
      let wm = $('#WelcomeModule')
      let currentDate = new Date()
      let expirationDate = new Date(currentDate.getFullYear(), currentDate.getMonth(), currentDate.getDate(), 23, 59, 59)

      $.cookie('st_welcome', 'viewed', {
        path: '/',
        expires: expirationDate,
        domain: '.startribune.com'
      })

      wm.click(function (e) {
        let link = $(this).attr('href')
        if (!(link === undefined || link === null) && link !== '#comments' && link.length > 0) {
          e.preventDefault()
          let windowFeatures = 'status=no,height=300,width=500,toolbar=no,menubar=no,scrollbars=no,location=no,directories=no'
          window.open(link, 'sharer', windowFeatures)
        }
      })
    })
  }

  function closeWelcome () {
    document.body.scrollTop = document.documentElement.scrollTop = 0
    document.getElementById('WelcomeModule').style.display = 'none'
    //Analytics should be caught with jQuery later.
  }

  function populateWelcome () {
    document.getElementById('WelcomeModule').style.display = 'block'
    document.getElementById('welcome-close').onclick = closeWelcome
    setTimeout(closeWelcome, 12000)
    AddWelcomeAd()
    bindWelcome()
    if (!isGoogleBot()) {
      addPhoto()
    }
  }
</script>

        <script type="text/javascript">
            function ourDomain() {
                var parts = location.hostname.split('.');
                var subdomain = parts.shift();
                var upperleveldomain = parts.join('.');

                return (upperleveldomain == 'startribune.com');
            }

            function are_cookies_enabled() {
                if ( typeof $ === 'undefined' || !$.hasOwnProperty('cookie') ) {
                    return false;
                }
                var date = new Date();
                date.setTime(date.getTime()+(60*1000));
                var expires = "; expires="+date.toUTCString();
                document.cookie= "testcookie = ytubrute" + expires; //iPad does not create the cookie without a value.
                var cookieEnabled = (document.cookie.indexOf("testcookie") != -1) ? true : false;

                return (cookieEnabled);
            }

            if (ourDomain() && are_cookies_enabled() && !isPhone() && typeof populateWelcome !== 'undefined') {
                var welcomeCookieVal = document.cookie.indexOf("st_welcome");
                if(welcomeCookieVal == undefined ||  welcomeCookieVal == null || welcomeCookieVal < 0){
                    setTimeout(populateWelcome, 10);
                }
            }
        </script>

            var linkPosition = positions.shift();
            if (isNaN(Number(linkPosition))) {
                modulePosition += '-' + linkPosition;
                linkPosition = positions.shift();
            }
            if (positions.length) {
                linkPosition += '-' + positions.join('-');
            }
            var key = zonetype + '-' + moduletype + '-' + modulename;
            var contentType = '';
            if ( $this !== false && $this.data('contenttype') ) {
                contentType = $this.data('contenttype');
            }
            var vars = {
                'key':key,
                'linkname':linkname,
                'linktype':linktype,
                'modulename':modulename,
                'moduletype':moduletype,
                'zonetype':zonetype,
                'contentType':contentType,
                'modulePosition':modulePosition,
                'linkPosition':linkPosition,
                'events':events,
            };
            if (typeof share !== 'undefined') {
                vars['share'] = share;
            }
            trackClick( vars );
        }
    }
</script>

<script>
    // Create an observer to track page performance and send to analytics from the footer
    let firstPaint
    let firstContentfulPaint
    const observer = new PerformanceObserver((list) => {
      for (const entry of list.getEntries()) {
        let time = Math.round(entry.startTime + entry.duration)
        if (entry.name === 'first-paint') {
          firstPaint = time
        } else {
          firstContentfulPaint = time
        }
      }
    })
    // Start observing the entry types you care about.
    observer.observe({entryTypes: ['paint']})
</script>

                                            <div class="article-body resizeFont">
                                                                                    
                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                    
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">After surviving some of the bloodiest combat in Afghanistan, the men of the 2nd Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment stayed connected on social media for support at home as they dealt with the fallout of war.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">It was a rough transition to civilian life. Many were disillusioned about why they fought; others struggled with post-traumatic stress. Suicide stalked their ranks. Those close online connections offered something the veterans' health care system did not: common ground, understanding, friends ready to talk.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">But the connections that held strong through all those troubles have been frayed to breaking by the partisan rancor of 2020. The Facebook group the men once relied on for support is now clogged with divisive memes and partisan conspiracy theories, disputes over policing and protests, and, of course, strong views on the president.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">The din has driven a growing number of members to log off in dismay. Many say they still want to support their fellow Marines but cannot stand the toxic political traffic.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">Party strategists and analysts tend to treat veterans as a homogeneous voting bloc, conservative-leaning and focused mainly on defense and benefits issues. But veterans are increasingly diverse in their outlook and deeply divided over the election.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">The explosive issues of a strange year and the unconventional presidency of Donald Trump have pried veterans apart, just as they have divided families at kitchen tables and friends in now-canceled softball leagues. Like many other Americans, veterans can find it hard even to agree to disagree when so many see November as a critical turning point.<div class="related-media ">
    <div class="related-media-wrapper is-"><!-- add .is-photo, .is-gallery, .is-graphic, .is-video -->
                    
            
            <div id="strib-image-294293561">
                <script type="text/javascript">
                    StarTribune.react.singleImage('strib-image-294293561', {
                        photo: {"url":"http:\/\/stmedia.startribune.com\/images\/ows_2d344eaf-f7b2-40b6-ace4-dd2fefebd141.jpg","caption":"Ruben Sevilla, a former lance corporal, who keeps in touch with a small group of friends from the battalion, in Oswego, Ill., Oct. 1, 2020. He said he has drifted away from the larger group in part because of the partisan bickering. Toxic rhetoric and political polarization are doing what nothing else could: driving apart ex-Marines who had one another\u2019s backs through wars and the stresses of civilian life. (Taylor Glascock\/The New York Times)","author":null,"credit":null,"altText":"Ruben Sevilla, a former lance corporal, who keeps in touch with a small group of friends from the battalion, in Oswego, Ill., Oct. 1, 2020. He said he"},
                        hideCaptionAndCredit: true,
                        analyticsUrlBase: 'https://smetrics.startribune.com/b/ss/nmminneapolis/1/JS-2.9.0',
                        analytics: JSON.parse('{"pageName":"pageName=Bonds%20formed%20in%20battle%20tested%20by%202020%20rancor","channel":"channel=Photo Gallery","server":"server=startribune.com","prop1":"c1=https%3A%2F%2Fstmedia.stimg.co%2Fows_2d344eaf-f7b2-40b6-ace4-dd2fefebd141.jpg%3Fw%3D263","prop3":"c3=Photo","prop4":"c4=Photo Gallery","prop5":"c5=","prop7":"c7=Photography","prop16":"c16=","prop24":"c24=Photo Gallery","prop31":"c31=Related Article Single Image","prop33":"c33=","prop64":"c64="}')
                    });
                </script>
            </div>
            </div>
                        <div class="related-byline">
                
            </div>
                            <div class="related-caption toggle-photo-caption">
                                    Ruben Sevilla, a former lance corporal, who keeps in touch with a small group of friends from the battalion, in Oswego, Ill., Oct. 1, 2020. He said he has drifted away from the larger group in part because of the partisan bickering. Toxic rhetoric and political polarization are doing what nothing else could: driving apart ex-Marines who had one another’s backs through wars and the stresses of civilian life. (Taylor Glascock/The New York Times)
                            </div>
                            <button class="ellipsis-more-less"></button>            
    
    </div></p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">And those cracks are clear among the veterans of the 2/7. Many from the battalion have unfollowed longtime friends. Some have left the unit's online support group entirely.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">"It hurts my soul to see all this childish drama," said Keith Branch, a former infantryman from the battalion. "Brothers that formed bonds in war, I see them becoming broken over childish arguments. I disconnect from it — I'm already dealing with post-traumatic stress. It hurts too much to look at it."</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">In 2015, veterans of the battalion's combat deployments had a suicide rate 14 times the national average, and Branch, who lives in Texas, helped to set up the rapid response network of volunteers who could race to the scene when a fellow battalion veteran was contemplating suicide. The group made several critical interventions to save lives.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">Now, he said, members of the Facebook group are much less willing to open up amid the partisan hostility, and real discussion about the fallout of combat has grown rare.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">"People are saying they are never going to talk to each other again," said Branch, who does not plan to vote this year. "I don't get it. We went to war to fight extremism. I don't understand why we can't find common ground."</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">Danny Kwan was one of many Marines who nearly killed himself after coming home. With the support of friends from the battalion, he graduated from college, interned for a congresswoman and became a firefighter. He has backed both Democrats and Republicans over the years. This year he plans to vote for Joe Biden, he said, primarily because he is wary of a second Trump term.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">In 2016, exit polls showed that veterans backed Trump over Hillary Clinton by nearly 2 to 1. Veterans skew old and male and white, and so does the core of Trump's support.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">As a candidate in 2016, Trump blasted the politicians and generals who had perpetuated the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and had ignored problems with veterans' health care, former Marine Alex McCoy said. "He picked the right enemies, he was yelling at the right people," McCoy said.</p>

                                                                                                                                                
                            
                                                                                                    <p class="Text_Body">It is unclear now whether Trump will be able to muster as much support.</p>

      function getZone3 () {
        $.ajax({
          async: true,
          method: 'GET',
          url: '/lazy/zone3/Nation/zone_detail-267/0/0',
          success: function (response) {
            $(document.getElementById('zone3')).html(response)
          }
        })
      }

      function trackScroll () {
        var element_position = $('.l-article-downpage-more-feed').offset().top
        var screen_height = $(window).height()
        var activation_offset = 0.5//determines how far up the the page the element needs to be before triggering the function
        var activation_point = element_position - (screen_height * activation_offset)
        var max_scroll_height = $('body').height() - screen_height - 5//-5 for a little bit of buffer
        var y_scroll_pos = window.pageYOffset
        var element_in_view = y_scroll_pos > activation_point
        var has_reached_bottom_of_page = max_scroll_height <= y_scroll_pos && !element_in_view
        if (element_in_view || has_reached_bottom_of_page) {
          getZone3()
          window.removeEventListener('scroll', trackScroll, false)  //Remove trackScroll once the zone is loaded
        }
      }
      if ($(".l-article-downpage-more-feed")[0]) {
        window.addEventListener('scroll', trackScroll, false)
        trackScroll()
      }
    </script>

summary:
Those close online connections offered something the veterans' health care system did not: common ground, understanding, friends ready to talk.
But the connections that held strong through all those troubles have been frayed to breaking by the partisan rancor of 2020.
Ruben Sevilla, a former lance corporal, who keeps in touch with a small group of friends from the battalion, in Oswego, Ill., Oct. 1, 2020.
Some have left the unit's online support group entirely.
With the support of friends from the battalion, he graduated from college, interned for a congresswoman and became a firefighter.
title: Bonds formed in battle tested by 2020 rancor

text:
Defense Minister Benny Gantz on Sunday held as a first-of-its-kind town hall with Arab journalists, highlighting efforts by Turkey and Iran to destabilize the region and undermine efforts to achieve peace.

Among those taking part were Mohamed Al Hammadi, the editor of the UAE-based Alroeya newspaper, and Ahdeya Ahmed Al-Sayed of Bahrain, who, during a webinar last week, described harassment he faced for taking part in a previous unprecedented online forum that brought together more than a dozen Arab media people and Israeli journalists and government officials.

They were joined by two Saudi journalists and other colleagues in the session with Gantz, which was organized and sponsored by the Arab Council for Regional Integration, according to the council’s general organizer Joseph Braude.

Get The Times of Israel's Daily Edition by email and never miss our top stories Free Sign Up

During the call, Gantz focused on efforts by Turkey and Iran to undermine the recently signed normalization agreements between Israel and the UAE and Bahrain, and their continued support for conflicts in the region.

He accused the two nations of “denying promotion of peace and supporting regional aggression.”

While Israel frequently slams arch-foe Iran, public criticism of Turkey, which still maintains relations with Israel, is rare.

Gantz highlighted Ankara’s involvement in the civil war in Libya, naval tensions with Greece and Cyprus over natural gas exploration in the Eastern Mediterranean, Turkish involvement in the Syrian civil war, and its close ties with the Palestinian terror group Hamas, saying that this “pushes away from stability.”

Gantz noted that dealing with Turkey was complicated by the fact that it was a member of NATO.

“So we must take all the options that we have in our hands and try to influence it through international pressure to make sure that they are pulling their hands from direct terrorism,” he said in the hour-long Zoom call.

On Iran, Gantz said Israel’s new ties with Sunni Arab nations provided further means for confronting Tehran.

“We have the strategic tools to face Iran. We are stronger than them. Our collaborations give us new strategies and options, and the Iranians understand that too. The best strategy for regional stability is peace,” he said.

Gantz said he hoped normalization would provide tools to help combat radical extremists. “We need to be able to offer a better alternative, to show the positive outcomes of moderation,” he said. “We have so much to offer each other. Israel has largely been an island, but we have so much to offer and so much to receive. There is no better strategy than actual human ties.”

Gantz told participants that despite being a general, he has a deep commitment to peace and shared an anecdote about how his first operational mission as an Israel Defense Forces soldier was to secure the convoy of Egyptian president Anwar Sadat as he came to Israel to make peace.

Gantz also called on Arab states to confront the terror groups operating from their territory, singling out Lebanon and Hezbollah.

“I demand that states be held responsible. Lebanon cannot allow Hezbollah to operate against Israel from within Lebanon and later say, ‘Sorry, that isn’t us,'” Gantz said.

“Any country that faces these types of threats must be able to act against the direct threat posed by the militia, but also against the government hosting it,” he said.

In 1st town hall with Gulf and Saudi reporters, Gantz says Turkey opposes peace

Defense minister tells journalists that deterring Ankara from destabilizing region is complicated by it being a NATO member, calls for international pressure

By TOI staff Today, 2:38 am 0 Edit

  • Twitter
  • linkedin
  • email
