    <script>
        
            var bFoundOrigin = true;
            var sOriginID = null;
        
        var sOriginURL = scrubURL('https://news.lee.net/tncms/search/mlt/?origin=28f66dd0-8057-5f4b-a1bb-f5e08fda0a63&app=editorial&inline=infinity&type=article%2Ccollection%2Cvideo%2Cyoutube'); // original url scrubbed for preview
        var sFirstID = null;
        var bFirstRun = true;
        var bShowAd = true;
        var bInfiniStop = false;
        var sInfinityType = 'summary_siderail';

        function populateInfinitySet(sURL) {
            sURL = scrubURL(sURL);

            // Until the origin paramter for cms.search.mlt functions, we have to start/stop the looping on our own
            // This will require not displaying any assets until we hit oAsset.
            // Then we loop through and display until we've been through everything up to our origin

            $.ajax(sURL).then(function(oResponse, sStatus, oXHR) {

                var sNextUrl = null;

                if (typeof oResponse.next_url == 'undefined') {
                    // URL supplied is no good. Revert to original URL
                    sNextUrl = sOriginURL;
                } else {
                    sNextUrl = scrubURL(oResponse.next_url);
                }

                // Manage response
                if (typeof oResponse.assets != 'undefined' && oResponse.assets.length > 0) {
                    
                    // Remove old more data
                    $("#infinite-more").remove();

                    
                    // Build infinity set
                    $.each(oResponse.assets, function(index) {
                            if (index == 1 && sOriginID == null) {
                                sOriginID = oResponse.assets[0].id;
                            }
                        // Display assets once origin is found
                        if (bFoundOrigin == true) {
                            if (this.id == sOriginID) {
                                bInfiniStop = true;
                                sNextUrl = null;
                                $("#infinite-more").remove();
                                
                            } else if (bInfiniStop == false && this.id != '28f66dd0-8057-5f4b-a1bb-f5e08fda0a63') {
                                // Display asset
                                var sHTML = '';
                                if (this.content) {
                                    if (sInfinityType == 'summary_sticky_siderail') {
                                        sHTML += '<div class="infinite-item original row"><div class="col-md-12">' + this.content + '</div></div><hr>';
                                    } else {
                                        sHTML += '<div class="infinite-item original row"><div class="col-md-8">' + this.content + '</div><div class="col-md-4 text-center">';
                                        if (bShowAd == true) {
                                            // Show advertisement
                                            sHTML += '<div class="infinity-ad empty"></div>'
                                            bShowAd = false;
                                        } else {
                                            bShowAd = true;
                                        }
                                        sHTML += '</div></div><hr>';
                                    }
                                }
                            }
                        } else {
                            if (this.id == sOriginID) {
                                // Origin found. Begin displaying assets
                                bFoundOrigin = true;
                            } else {
                                // Origin found is false. Skip asset
                                // Fail-safe in case origin is not present in set. This can be removed when origin is fixed.
                                if (bFirstRun == true) {
                                    // Stored first id
                                    sFirstID = this.id;
                                    bFirstRun = false;
                                } else if (this.id == sFirstID) {
                                    // We've started again. Force origin
                                    sOriginID = sFirstID;
                                    bFoundOrigin = true;
                                } // end Fail-safe
                            }
                        }
                        // Append infinity set to container
                        $("#infinite-container").append(sHTML);
                    });

                    // Include block_id on newly added list items
                    $('#infinite-container .infinite-item.original').each(function() {
                        var sHref = scrubURL($(this).find(".card-headline a").attr("href"));
                        
                        // Add to image and headlines links
                        $(this).removeClass('original')
                            .find(".card-headline a, .image a")
                            .attr("href", sHref + "#tncms-source=infinity-scroll-summary-siderail-latest");
                    });

                    // Check next URL
                    if (sNextUrl) {
                        // if origin hasn't been found yet and we hit next_url. Trigger the set to pull in again.
                        if (bFoundOrigin == false) {
                            // No origin yet. Call the populate function
                            populateInfinitySet(sNextUrl);
                        } else {
                            // Append sNextUrl to infinity set
                            $("#infinite-container").append('<div id="infinite-more" data-next-url="' + sNextUrl + '"><i class="fas tnt-spinner tnt-pulse"></i></div>');
                        }
                    }
                    
                        // Ad waypoint and handler to insert ads next to summary
                        $('.infinity-ad.empty').waypoint({
                            offset: '80%',
                            handler: function(direction) {
                                // Kill waypoint
                                this.destroy();
                                $(this.element).removeClass('empty');
                                // Create and append ad iframe. Make sure this occurs only once
                                var newIframe = infinityAd();
                                if($(this.element).children().length <= 0) {
                                    $(this.element).append(newIframe);
                                }
                            }
                        });
                    
                    // Refresh waypoints
                    Waypoint.refreshAll();
                    if (sInfinityType == 'summary_sticky_siderail') {
                        __tnt.regions.stickySide.determineStick($('#sticky-right-rail'), $('#sticky-right-rail-spacer'), 'siderail');
                    }
                } else {
                    // Empty asset set returned. Go back in for a real set
                    populateInfinitySet(sNextUrl);
                }
            });
        }

        // Infinite waypoint
        var waypoint = new Waypoint({
            element: document.getElementById('infinite-container'),
            handler: function(direction) {
                if (direction == 'down') {
                    if (bInfiniStop == true) {                        
                        // FINISHED. Kill the waypoint
                        this.destroy();
                    } else {
                        // Log waypoint hit event
                        __tnt.trackEvent({'category':'infinity-scroll','action':'request', 'label':'assets requested', 'value': true});
                        var nextURL =  $('#infinite-more').data('next-url');
                        populateInfinitySet($('#infinite-more').data('next-url'));
                    }
                }
            },
            offset: 'bottom-in-view'
        });

        // Infinity ad
        function infinityAd() {
            var newIframe = document.createElement('iframe');
            newIframe.scrolling = 'no';
            newIframe.src = 'https://news.lee.net/tncms/block/1507052/?disableTNStatsTracker=1';
            return newIframe;
        }
        // Rewrite URL to for preview
        function scrubURL(sURL) {
            if (typeof sURL != 'undefined'){
                return sURL;
            }
        }
    </script>

text:
Shadow of doubt over Armenia-Azerbaijan dispute

IRNA - Islamic Republic News Agency

Tehran, Oct 4, IRNA -- Clashes between Armenia and the over the Nagorno-Karabakh region is continuing at a time while numerous international requests for putting an end to the dispute between the two countries has not worked and there are serious concerns over the deterioration of the situation.

The Armenian foreign ministry on Friday voiced that country's readiness to engage in negotiations with Azerbaijan in a bid to put an end to the dispute and an advisor to Azerbaijan's president, Hekmat Hajiev also said that the resumption of negotiations will be possible after the Armenian forces exit the Nagorno-Karabakh region.

The two sides might be ready and willing to hold talks, but it seems that the intensity of the clashes is to such extent that neither side is ready to bring to a halt the attacks, and the minimum conditions for peace are not prepared at this point.

Meantime, numerous requests by the world countries and officials from Armenia and Azerbaijan to establish a ceasefire have not worked and the two countries are still engaged in exchanging fires.

International bodies such as the United Nations (UN), Minsk Group, and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) could not take effective measures to stop the clashes between the two countries. For the same reason the effectiveness of these bodies' performance in resolving the international disputes has come under question or they cannot resolve these tensions or there is no serious political determination among the countries and the bodies dealing with the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute to restore the ceasefire in that region.

The political experts believe that it is not likely that Armenia and Azerbaijan would come to the negotiating table at this point.

The expert on Central Asia, Feodore Lukianov, said in this regard that he did not think that the two countries would have serious wills for negotiations.

He went to say that the conditions are such that it is hard to expect one side will cease the exchange of fire and return to the negotiating table.

As Baku has announced that it will take part in the negotiations only if Armenia unconditionally exits the Nagorno-Karabakh region and it has made the situation more complicated.

The dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan originally erupted over the mountainous region of Nagorno-Karabakh and changed into a six-year war (1988-1994), Armenia took control of the region, as well as seven counties around it. Some 35,000 people were killed and 800,000 were displaced.

In May 1994, the two countries accepted a ceasefire, but international efforts of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), aka Minsk Group, have been fruitless so far.

2050**2050

text:
Exclusive Stuff on the ground footage of the fire ravaged buildings in Lake Ōhau village.

Firefighters will work through the night to deal with any flare-ups after a massive fire at Lake Ōhau ripped through 5360 hectares and damaged 46 homes.

Fire and Emergency New Zealand (Fenz) incident controller Rob Hands said a drone equipped with an infrared camera would be deployed on Monday night to look for hotspots along the perimeter of the fire.

The fire erupted early Sunday and quickly spread through the lakeside village, located near Twizel in the Waitaki Basin.

It was contained on Monday, but crews would work through the night to deal with any flare-ups threatening properties that escaped damage on Sunday, Hands said. Helicopters and ground crews would be back at work at first light.

READ MORE:

* Eyewitness describes scenes of devastation at Lake Ōhau

* Remote Lake Ōhau an increasingly popular place

* High winds to remain a problem in devastating Lake Ohau firefight



Earlier on Monday, Fenz incident controller Graeme Still told media on a tour of the Lake Ōhau Village that the fire was the biggest in terms of destruction in his 40 years of firefighting.

Joanne Holden/Stuff Fire and Emergency New Zealand's Te Kei region manager Mike Grant, left, and incident controller Graeme Still update media on a bus tour of the fire-damaged Lake Ohau Village.

Fenz Te Kei region manager Mike Grant said it had been a huge firefighting effort.

"You have to be really on the button,'' he said.

He said gullies around the hills acted like a chimney, which meant there was very little fire suppression.

"When we get into areas where the standing trees are, we're talking 50, 80, 100 tonne per hectare, what that does is increases the intensity of fire and makes it more difficult to suppress.”

Still earlier revealed the fight against the blaze was going well.

"The fire is what we call contained, and we're on top of it, but never say never with these winds.”

Joanne Holden/Stuff Twisted corrugated iron in the remains of a fire razed dwelling in Lake Ohau Village.

The media bus tour followed an announcement that the Government would provide $100,000 as an initial contribution to help those affected by the fire.

Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare announced the fund as he offered his thoughts to residents.

"What we've just witnessed is completely devastating for the people of this community,'' he said.

"All of the feedback we've had from Fenz is that this is a significant event.

Bejon Haswell/Stuff Officials update media on the situation at Lake Ōhau.

"We will work closely with the mayor here and the Waitaki District Council on an ongoing basis and will assess their need and step in and support where we can."

Conservation Minister Eugenie Sage acknowledged the "devastating loss" for residents and those who had homes in Lake Ōhau.

She described seeing cars “with melted tyres, bunk bed frames and houses completely gone”.

About 1800ha of conservation land had been affected by the fire.

JOHN KIRK-ANDERSON/Stuff Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare in Twizel on Monday.

She said land management "had to be looked at" given the changing climate.

“We need to be fire smart in the future."

Waitaki District mayor Gary Kircher described the event as “absolutely devastating” for the community, but said a lot of people were already talking about rebuilding.

It was a “minor miracle” no-one was harmed.

“The reality is that another 15 or 20 minutes could've been a very different story."

Breakfast Waitaki mayor Gary Kircher reveals a dog had alerted a building owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau that has damaged or destroyed 40-50 structures.

Kircher had already heard several stories of heroism, including a man who woke up to his dog about 3am on Sunday.

“He went out opened the door and just saw a wall of orange coming towards the village, he shot down and turned on the village alarm and that helped get a lot of people out of bed and then the residents went door to door making sure that everyone was aware and able to get out.

"Actions like that which have helped save lives."

1 NEWS Steve Simmons, who does not live in the Lake Ohau area, was holidaying at the time and says there is “nothing left” of the brick home he owned.

Kircher said the community’s response showed some “pretty good presence of thought”.

“It's a testament to the plan the community had for such an event ... they were well-prepared, they've done their practices.”

Graham Smith, mayor of the neighbouring Mackenzie district, said the Twizel community's support for homeowners affected by the fire was "absolutely wonderful".

"Over 100 people ended up staying in Twizel from Lake Ōhau village overnight.

"This fire is in Waitaki's patch, but it's a much larger fire than the one in Pukaki a few weeks ago. That one stretched about 300ha, this one has spread about 1600ha.”

CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff The remains of dwellings destroyed by fire at Lake Åhau.

Smith said some farmers had lost stock, and many homes were destroyed.

"It's a huge loss," he said.

MetService spokeswoman Melissa Oosterwijk said gusts in the area overnight Sunday reached 60kmh to 65kmh and there was no rainfall.

MetService issued a strong wind warning for the Canterbury High Country from 10am Monday to 9am Tuesday.

At 6.40am, nearby Lake Pukaki was already at 16 degrees Celsius.

Andrew Turton/Supplied The Lake Ōhau fire burning at 4.10am on Sunday.

‘Monstrous orange maelstrom’

Those behind a Lake Ōhau bed and breakfast business confirmed in a Facebook post on Monday that they had lost their home.

The Barn at Killin said the family running the business was safe and were being looked after by friends.

Owner Hugh Spiers told Stuff the experience was like a lot of horror movies rolled into one.

“The smoke, the heat, the sparks and the unknowing, but yet in the back of your mind, there's a glimmer of hope going 'oh, this will be alright in the morning’.

“But it's not.”

The Facebook post said the family’s “home & business and a lifetime of memories are gone apart from the clothes on our backs”.

Stuff This montage shows the devastation at Lake Ohau village.

“Sleep escapes me and I can’t get rid of the taste of smoke from my mouth or close my eyes without seeing a monstrous orange maelstrom roaring towards us.”

The post thanked friends, the community and guests from across the world for their messages of support.

Spiers said he was trying to keep a positive attitude after the blaze.

“Where's my glasses, where's my watch, where's my wallet, it's all burnt," he said.

“You can't buy undies in Twizel ... you can buy socks, but you can't buy undies.”

CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff A damaged lakefront property at Lake Ōhau.

Help for residents

The Waitaki Emergency Operations Centre was working with those affected by the fire to ascertain their needs over the coming days and weeks.

Three busloads of property owners were taken see the damage for themselves on Monday afternoon, while residents who needed to retrieve essential items from undamaged properties would be able to register to be escorted to and from their homes from Tuesday.

The managed access would be for urgent essential purposes, such as tradespeople retrieving tools or people needing medication.

CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff Damage in the Lake Ōhau village after the fire.

The access would be available between 10am and 2pm provided conditions are safe for entry, Hands said. Residents will be transported in and out in a Fire and Emergency vehicle.

"We appreciate how anxious people are to return home, or to retrieve personal possessions. We are providing escorted access as an interim step,” Hands said.

Affected residents were being provided with meal vouchers, access to emergency medication and everyone was given accommodation on Sunday night.

Incident controller Murray Linwood praised those affected for their evacuation effort.

He also thanked the Mackenzie and Waitaki communities for their offers of support.

Breakfast A large blaze ripped through Lake Ohau Village in the Waitaki District destroying many homes.

Coastguard support

About 10 Coastguard volunteers from Tekapo and Twizel spent a gruelling 12 hours on the wind-ravaged Lake Ōhau on Sunday, with the same numbers returning to the water at first light on Monday to continue supporting helicopters fighting the blaze.

Coastguard Southern regional manager Cheryl Moffat said they were looking at bringing in a relief crew from other parts of the South Island to take over the two boats on the lake watching over helicopter pilots.

"It's pretty hard on the volunteers, because the wind is strong and the lake is very rough,’’ she said.

The wind had caused waves of up to 4 metres in some parts of the lake.

"They're happy to do it to help the community. But they've been out there two days, and potentially we'll need to be out there for another day. We need to think about their health."

Nikki Adams/Supplied The fire near Lake Ohau on Sunday morning.

CAUSE OF FIRE NOT YET KNOWN

Network Waitaki chief executive Geoff Douch said the lines company had been "flat out" trying to help Ōhau locals and work with Fenz and other agencies involved.

"Any speculation on the cause [of the fire] is just that, speculation. We are working hard helping Fenz in their investigations," he said.

class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--responsive-16-9"><video id="video_217uee" width="100%" height="100%" data-account="3921507366001" data-player="Syx4Zr1Keb" sics-component__story-video__video--element video-js" poster="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/u/e/5/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217uee.png/1601789920393.jpg" controls=""></video></div></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Charlie O'Manning/STUFF</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Exclusive Stuff on the ground footage of the fire ravaged buildings in Lake Ōhau village.</div></figcaption></div></span><span><div class="sics-component__html-asset sics-component__html-asset--no-scale"><div id="html-asset__300000349" name="300000349" width="100%"></div></div></span><span class="sics-component__story__body sics-component__story__body--nativform"><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__intro sics-component__story__paragraph">Firefighters will work through the night to deal with any flare-ups after a massive fire at Lake Ōhau ripped through 5360 hectares and damaged 46 homes.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Fire and Emergency New Zealand (Fenz) incident controller Rob Hands said a drone equipped with an infrared camera would be deployed on Monday night to look for hotspots along the perimeter of the fire.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The fire erupted early Sunday and quickly spread through the lakeside village, located near Twizel in the Waitaki Basin.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> It was contained on Monday, but crews would work through the night to deal with any flare-ups threatening properties that escaped damage on Sunday, Hands said. Helicopters and ground crews would be back at work at first light.</p><div id="fourth-par-video" class="sics-component__oovvuu-recommendation"></div><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> <strong>READ MORE:<br> * <a href="https://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300123787/eyewitness-describes-scenes-of-devastation-at-lake-hau?rm=a">Eyewitness describes scenes of devastation at Lake Ōhau</a><br> * <a href="https://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300123622/remote-lake-hau-an-increasingly-popular-place?rm=a">Remote Lake Ōhau an increasingly popular place</a><br> * <a href="https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/122975420/high-winds-to-remain-a-problem-in-devastating-lake-ohau-firefight?rm=a">High winds to remain a problem in devastating Lake Ohau firefight</a><br> </strong></p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Earlier on Monday, Fenz incident controller Graeme Still told media on a tour of the Lake Ōhau Village that the fire was the biggest in terms of destruction in his 40 years of firefighting.</p><span></span><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/p/p/j/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="Fire and Emergency New Zealand's Te Kei region manager Mike Grant, left, and incident controller Graeme Still update media on a bus tour of the fire-damaged Lake Ohau Village." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Joanne Holden/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Fire and Emergency New Zealand's Te Kei region manager Mike Grant, left, and incident controller Graeme Still update media on a bus tour of the fire-damaged Lake Ohau Village.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Fenz Te Kei region manager Mike Grant said it had been a huge firefighting effort.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "You have to be really on the button,'' he said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> He said gullies around the hills acted like a chimney, which meant there was very little fire suppression.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "When we get into areas where the standing trees are, we're talking 50, 80, 100 tonne per hectare, what that does is increases the intensity of fire and makes it more difficult to suppress.”</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Still earlier revealed the fight against the blaze was going well.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "The fire is what we call contained, and we're on top of it, but never say never with these winds.”</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/p/p/k/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="Twisted corrugated iron in the remains of a fire razed dwelling in Lake Ohau Village." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Joanne Holden/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Twisted corrugated iron in the remains of a fire razed dwelling in Lake Ohau Village.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The media bus tour followed an announcement that the Government would provide $100,000 as an initial contribution to help those affected by the fire.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare announced the fund as he offered his thoughts to residents.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "What we've just witnessed is completely devastating for the people of this community,'' he said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "All of the feedback we've had from Fenz is that this is a significant event.</p><span><div class="sics-component__story-video"><div class="sics-component__story-video__video" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/VideoObject"><meta itemProp="name" content="Officials update media on the situation at Lake Ōhau"/><meta itemProp="headline" content="Officials update media on the situation at Lake Ōhau"/><meta itemProp="description" content="Officials update media on the situation at Lake Ōhau."/><meta itemProp="thumbnailUrl" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/8/0/a/f/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.2180b6.png/1601861552606.jpg"/><meta itemProp="uploadDate" content="2020-10-05T01:24:48.170Z"/><meta itemProp="contentUrl" content="https://media.stuff.co.nz/video/production/1601860412335-STUFF_7.mp4"/><div class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--responsive-16-9"><video id="video_2180b6" width="100%" height="100%" data-account="3921507366001" data-player="Syx4Zr1Keb" poster="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/8/0/a/f/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.2180b6.png/1601861552606.jpg" controls=""></video></div></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Bejon Haswell/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Officials update media on the situation at Lake Ōhau.</div></figcaption></div></span><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "We will work closely with the mayor here and the Waitaki District Council on an ongoing basis and will assess their need and step in and support where we can."</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Conservation Minister Eugenie Sage acknowledged the "devastating loss" for residents and those who had homes in Lake Ōhau.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> She described seeing cars “with melted tyres, bunk bed frames and houses completely gone”.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> About 1800ha of conservation land had been affected by the fire.</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/p/6/m/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare in Twizel on Monday." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">JOHN KIRK-ANDERSON/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare in Twizel on Monday.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> She said land management "had to be looked at" given the changing climate.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “We need to be fire smart in the future."</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Waitaki District mayor Gary Kircher described the event as “absolutely devastating” for the community, but said a lot of people were already talking about rebuilding. </p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> It was a “minor miracle” no-one was harmed.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “The reality is that another 15 or 20 minutes could've been a very different story."</p><span><div class="sics-component__story-video"><div class="sics-component__story-video__video" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/VideoObject"><meta itemProp="name" content="Dog alerted owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau"/><meta itemProp="headline" content="Dog alerted owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau"/><meta itemProp="description" content="Waitaki mayor Gary Kircher reveals a dog had alerted a building owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau that has damaged or destroyed 40-50 structures."/><meta itemProp="thumbnailUrl" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/w/5/s/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217w5t.png/1601846714951.jpg"/><meta itemProp="uploadDate" class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--responsive-16-9"><video id="video_217w5t" width="100%" height="100%" data-account="3921507366001" data-player="Syx4Zr1Keb" data-embed="default" data-video-id="ref:217w5t" data-video-headline="Dog alerted owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau" data-video-suppress-ads="false" class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--element video-js" poster="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/w/5/s/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217w5t.png/1601846714951.jpg" controls=""></video></div></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Breakfast</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Waitaki mayor Gary Kircher reveals a dog had alerted a building owner to massive fire burning at Lake Ōhau that has damaged or destroyed 40-50 structures.</div></figcaption></div></span><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Kircher had already heard several stories of heroism, including a man who woke up to his dog about 3am on Sunday.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “He went out opened the door and just saw a wall of orange coming towards the village, he shot down and turned on the village alarm and that helped get a lot of people out of bed and then the residents went door to door making sure that everyone was aware and able to get out.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "Actions like that which have helped save lives."</p><span><div class="sics-component__story-video"><div class="sics-component__story-video__video" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/VideoObject"><meta itemProp="name" content="‘Complete devastation’ - Lake Ohau Village homeowner loses two properties in blaze"/><meta itemProp="headline" content="‘Complete devastation’ - Lake Ohau Village homeowner loses two properties in blaze"/><meta itemProp="description" content="Steve Simmons, who does not live in the Lake Ohau area, was holidaying at the time and says there is “nothing left” of the brick home he owned."/><meta itemProp="thumbnailUrl" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/u/d/h/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217udk.png/1601874348598.jpg"/><meta itemProp="uploadDate" content="2020-10-04T21:17:22.812Z"/><meta itemProp="contentUrl" content="https://media.stuff.co.nz/video/production/brightcove/52955c5a38962c9f31e488248aee827a.mp4"/><div class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--responsive-16-9"><video id="video_217udk" width="100%" height="100%" data-account="3921507366001" data-player="Syx4Zr1Keb" data-embed="default" data-video-id="ref:217udk" data-video-headline="‘Complete devastation’ - Lake Ohau Village homeowner loses two properties in blaze" data-video-suppress-ads="false" class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--element video-js" poster="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/u/d/h/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217udk.png/1601874348598.jpg" controls=""></video></div></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">1 NEWS</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Steve Simmons, who does not live in the Lake Ohau area, was holidaying at the time and says there is “nothing left” of the brick home he owned.</div></figcaption></div></span><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Kircher said the community’s response showed some “pretty good presence of thought”.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “It's a testament to the plan the community had for such an event ... they were well-prepared, they've done their practices.”</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph">  Graham Smith, mayor of the neighbouring Mackenzie district, said the Twizel community's support for homeowners affected by the fire was "absolutely wonderful".</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "Over 100 people ended up staying in Twizel from Lake Ōhau village overnight.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "This fire is in Waitaki's patch, but it's a much larger fire than <a href="http://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300095062/aorakimt-cook-evacuated-in-the-face-of-massive-mackenzie-district-scrubfire">the one in Pukaki</a> a few weeks ago. That one stretched about 300ha, this one has spread about 1600ha.”</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/y/z/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="The remains of dwellings destroyed by fire at Lake Åhau." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">The remains of dwellings destroyed by fire at Lake Åhau.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Smith said some farmers had lost stock, and many homes were destroyed.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "It's a huge loss," he said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> MetService spokeswoman Melissa Oosterwijk said gusts in the area overnight Sunday reached 60kmh to 65kmh and there was no rainfall.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> MetService <a href="https://twitter.com/MetService/status/1312498027429466115?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet">issued a strong wind warning for the Canterbury High Country</a> from 10am Monday to 9am Tuesday.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> At 6.40am, nearby Lake Pukaki was already at 16 degrees Celsius.</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/q/v/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="The Lake Ōhau fire burning at 4.10am on Sunday." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Andrew Turton/Supplied</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">The Lake Ōhau fire burning at 4.10am on Sunday.</div></figcaption></figure><h3 class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> ‘Monstrous orange maelstrom’</h3><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Those behind a Lake Ōhau bed and breakfast business confirmed <a href="https://www.facebook.com/TheBarnBB/posts/1455406441326427">in a Facebook post</a> on Monday that they had lost their home.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The Barn at Killin said the family running the business was safe and were being looked after by friends.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Owner Hugh Spiers told <em>Stuff</em> the experience was like a lot of horror movies rolled into one.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “The smoke, the heat, the sparks and the unknowing, but yet in the back of your mind, there's a glimmer of hope going 'oh, this will be alright in the morning’.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “But it's not.”</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The Facebook post said the family’s “home & business and a lifetime of memories are gone apart from the clothes on our backs”.</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/t/z/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="This montage shows the devastation at Lake Ohau village." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">This montage shows the devastation at Lake Ohau village.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “Sleep escapes me and I can’t get rid of the taste of smoke from my mouth or close my eyes without seeing a monstrous orange maelstrom roaring towards us.”</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The post thanked friends, the community and guests from across the world for their messages of support.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Spiers said he was trying to keep a positive attitude after the blaze.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “Where's my glasses, where's my watch, where's my wallet, it's all burnt," he said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> “You can't buy undies in Twizel ... you can buy socks, but you can't buy undies.”</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/y/w/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="A damaged lakefront property at Lake Ōhau." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">A damaged lakefront property at Lake Ōhau.</div></figcaption></figure><h3 class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Help for residents</h3><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The Waitaki Emergency Operations Centre was working with those affected by the fire to ascertain their needs over the coming days and weeks.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Three busloads of property owners were taken see the damage for themselves on Monday afternoon, while residents who needed to retrieve essential items from undamaged properties would be able to register to be escorted to and from their homes from Tuesday.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The managed access would be for urgent essential purposes, such as tradespeople retrieving tools or people needing medication.</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/y/y/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="Damage in the Lake Ōhau village after the fire." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">Damage in the Lake Ōhau village after the fire.</div></figcaption></figure><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The access would be available between 10am and 2pm provided conditions are safe for entry, Hands said. Residents will be transported in and out in a Fire and Emergency vehicle.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "We appreciate how anxious people are to return home, or to retrieve personal possessions. We are providing escorted access as an interim step,” Hands said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Affected residents were being provided with meal vouchers, access to emergency medication and everyone was given accommodation on Sunday night.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Incident controller Murray Linwood praised those affected for their evacuation effort.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> He also thanked the Mackenzie and Waitaki communities for their offers of support.</p><span><div class="sics-component__story-video"><div class="sics-component__story-video__video" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/VideoObject"><meta itemProp="name" content="Fire crews work through the night to protect houses at Lake Ohau village"/><meta itemProp="headline" content="Fire crews work through the night to protect houses at Lake Ohau village"/><meta itemProp="description" content="A large blaze ripped through Lake Ohau Village in the Waitaki District destroying many homes."/><meta itemProp="thumbnailUrl" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/v/j/x/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217vjy.png/1601846212797.jpg"/><meta itemProp="uploadDate" content="2020-10-04T21:16:45.408Z"/><meta itemProp="contentUrl" content="https://media.stuff.co.nz/video/production/brightcove/e3ac8d2ce383cb8d240338a632d67b1a.mp4"/><div class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--responsive-16-9"><video id="video_217vjy" width="100%" height="100%" data-account="3921507366001" data-player="Syx4Zr1Keb" data-embed="default" data-video-id="ref:217vjy" data-video-headline="Fire crews work through the night to protect houses at Lake Ohau village" data-video-suppress-ads="false" class="sics-component__story-video__video sics-component__story-video__video--element video-js" poster="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/2/1/7/v/j/x/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.620x350.217vjy.png/1601846212797.jpg" controls=""></video></div></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Breakfast</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">A large blaze ripped through Lake Ohau Village in the Waitaki District destroying many homes.</div></figcaption></div></span><h3 class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Coastguard support</h3><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> About 10 Coastguard volunteers from Tekapo and Twizel spent a gruelling 12 hours on the wind-ravaged Lake Ōhau on Sunday, with the same numbers returning to the water at first light on Monday to continue supporting helicopters fighting the blaze.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Coastguard Southern regional manager Cheryl Moffat said they were looking at bringing in a relief crew from other parts of the South Island to take over the two boats on the lake watching over helicopter pilots.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "It's pretty hard on the volunteers, because the wind is strong and the lake is very rough,’’ she said.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> The wind had caused waves of up to 4 metres in some parts of the lake.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "They're happy to do it to help the community. But they've been out there two days, and potentially we'll need to be out there for another day. We need to think about their health."</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope="" itemType="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><meta itemProp="url" content="https://resources.stuff.co.nz/content/dam/images/4/y/o/o/u/z/image.related.StuffLandscapeSixteenByNine.710x400.217vho.png/1601881793024.jpg?format=pjpg&optimize=medium"/><img class="lazyimg" alt="The fire near Lake Ohau on Sunday morning." style="width:100%;display:inline-block"/></div><figcaption class="sics-component__caption"><div class="sics-component__caption__top-line"><span class="sics-component__caption__icon-text"></span><cite class="sics-component__caption__producer">Nikki Adams/Supplied</cite></div><div class="sics-component__caption__caption">The fire near Lake Ohau on Sunday morning.</div></figcaption></figure><h3 class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> CAUSE OF FIRE NOT YET KNOWN</h3><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> Network Waitaki chief executive Geoff Douch said the lines company had been "flat out" trying to help Ōhau locals and work with Fenz and other agencies involved.</p><p class="sics-component__html-injector sics-component__story__paragraph"> "Any speculation on the cause [of the fire] is just that, speculation. We are working hard helping Fenz in their investigations," he said.</p><figure class="sics-component__story-image"><div class="sics-component__story-image__image-wrapper" itemProp="image" itemscope=""   <script>
    window.__INITIAL_STATE__ = "{\"account\":{},\"app\":{\"sections\":[\"national\"],\"error\":false,\"status\":200},\"breakingNews\":{},\"gigya\":{},\"mostPopular\":{},\"news\":{\"122979372\":{\"viewing\":false,\"news\":{\"id\":\"122979372\",\"seoNoIndex\":false,\"sslEnabled\":true,\"headers\":{\"x-relates-to\":\"122979372 122977958 300000349 300124711 300124712 122985618 300124030 122980241 122977928 300123755 300123463 300123575 300123752 300123754 122979454 300123611 300124037 300069982 300124346 D20201005 Article\"},\"headline\":\"Lake Ōhau fire destroys over 5000ha and leaves 46 homes uninhabitable\",\"headlineFlags\":[\"VIDEO\"],\"advertisement\":false,\"sponsored\":false,\"byline\":\"Joanne Holden, Steven Walton and Sam Sherwood\",\"urlSlug\":\"lake-hau-fire-destroys-over-5000ha-and-leaves-46-homes-uninhabitable\",\"indexIntroText\":\"Firefighters will work through the night to deal with any flare-ups after a massive fire at Lake Ōhau ripped through 5360 hectares and damaged 46 homes.\",\"firstPublishTime\":\"2020-10-04T18:30:59.277Z\",\"lastBigModificationTime\":\"2020-10-05T07:09:49.239Z\",\"filteredBodyMarkup\":\"<p>Firefighters will work through the night to deal with any flare-ups after a massive fire at Lake Ōhau ripped through 5360 hectares and damaged 46 homes.</p> \\n<p>Fire and Emergency New Zealand (Fenz) incident controller Rob Hands said a drone equipped with an infrared camera would be deployed on Monday night to look for hotspots along the perimeter of the fire.</p> \\n<p>The fire erupted early Sunday and quickly spread through the lakeside village, located near Twizel in the Waitaki Basin.</p> \\n<p>It was contained on Monday, but crews would work through the night to deal with any flare-ups threatening properties that escaped damage on Sunday, Hands said. Helicopters and ground crews would be back at work at first light.</p> \\n<p><strong>READ MORE:<br> * <a href=\\\"https://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300123787/eyewitness-describes-scenes-of-devastation-at-lake-hau?rm=a\\\">Eyewitness describes scenes of devastation at Lake Ōhau</a><br> * <a href=\\\"https://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300123622/remote-lake-hau-an-increasingly-popular-place?rm=a\\\">Remote Lake Ōhau an increasingly popular place</a><br> * <a href=\\\"https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/122975420/high-winds-to-remain-a-problem-in-devastating-lake-ohau-firefight?rm=a\\\">High winds to remain a problem in devastating Lake Ohau firefight</a><br> </strong></p> \\n<p>Earlier on Monday, Fenz incident controller Graeme Still told media on a tour of the Lake Ōhau Village that the fire was the biggest in terms of destruction in his 40 years of firefighting.</p> \\n<p>Fenz Te Kei region manager Mike Grant said it had been a huge firefighting effort.</p> \\n<p>\\\"You have to be really on the button,'' he said.</p> \\n<p>He said gullies around the hills acted like a chimney, which meant there was very little fire suppression.</p> \\n<p>\\\"When we get into areas where the standing trees are, we're talking 50, 80, 100 tonne per hectare, what that does is increases the intensity of fire and makes it more difficult to suppress.”</p> \\n<p>Still earlier revealed the fight against the blaze was going well.</p> \\n<p>\\\"The fire is what we call contained, and we're on top of it, but never say never with these winds.”</p> \\n<p>The media bus tour followed an announcement that the Government would provide $100,000 as an initial contribution to help those affected by the fire.</p> \\n<p>Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare announced the fund as he offered his thoughts to residents.</p> \\n<p>\\\"What we've just witnessed is completely devastating for the people of this community,'' he said.</p> \\n<p>\\\"All of the feedback we've had from Fenz is that this is a significant event.</p> \\n<p>\\\"We will work closely with the mayor here and the Waitaki District Council on an ongoing basis and will assess their need and step in and support where we can.\\\"</p> \\n<p>Conservation Minister Eugenie Sage acknowledged the \\\"devastating loss\\\" for residents and those who had homes in Lake Ōhau.</p> \\n<p>She described seeing cars “with melted tyres, bunk bed frames and houses completely gone”.</p> \\n<p>About 1800ha of conservation land had been affected by the fire.</p> \\n<p>She said land management \\\"had to be looked at\\\" given the changing climate.</p> \\n<p>“We need to be fire smart in the future.\\\"</p> \\n<p>Waitaki District mayor Gary Kircher described the event as “absolutely devastating” for the community, but said a lot of people were already talking about rebuilding. </p> \\n<p>It was a “minor miracle” no-one was harmed.</p> \\n<p>“The reality is that another 15 or 20 minutes could've been a very different story.\\\"</p> \\n<p>Kircher had already heard several stories of heroism, including a man who woke up to his dog about 3am on Sunday.</p> \\n<p>“He went out opened the door and just saw a wall of orange coming towards the village, he shot down and turned on the village alarm and that helped get a lot of people out of bed and then the residents went door to door making sure that everyone was aware and able to get out.</p> \\n<p>\\\"Actions like that which have helped save lives.\\\"</p> \\n<p>Kircher said the community’s response showed some “pretty good presence of thought”.</p> \\n<p>“It's a testament to the plan the community had for such an event ... they were well-prepared, they've done their practices.”</p>  \\n<p>Graham Smith, mayor of the neighbouring Mackenzie district, said the Twizel community's support for homeowners affected by the fire was \\\"absolutely wonderful\\\".</p> \\n<p>\\\"Over 100 people ended up staying in Twizel from Lake Ōhau village overnight.</p> \\n<p>\\\"This fire is in Waitaki's patch, but it's a much larger fire than <a href=\\\"http://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300095062/aorakimt-cook-evacuated-in-the-face-of-massive-mackenzie-district-scrubfire\\\">the one in Pukaki</a> a few weeks ago. That one stretched about 300ha, this one has spread about 1600ha.”</p> \\n<p>Smith said some farmers had lost stock, and many homes were destroyed.</p> \\n<p>\\\"It's a huge loss,\\\" he said.</p> \\n<p>MetService spokeswoman Melissa Oosterwijk said gusts in the area overnight Sunday reached 60kmh to 65kmh and there was no rainfall.</p> \\n<p>MetService <a href=\\\"https://twitter.com/MetService/status/1312498027429466115?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet\\\">issued a strong wind warning for the Canterbury High Country</a> from 10am Monday to 9am Tuesday.</p> \\n<p>At 6.40am, nearby Lake Pukaki was already at 16 degrees Celsius.</p> \\n<h3>‘Monstrous orange maelstrom’</h3> \\n<p>Those behind a Lake Ōhau bed and breakfast business confirmed <a href=\\\"https://www.facebook.com/TheBarnBB/posts/1455406441326427\\\">in a Facebook post</a> on Monday that they had lost their home.</p> \\n<p>The Barn at Killin said the family running the business was safe and were being looked after by friends.</p> \\n<p>Owner Hugh Spiers told <em>Stuff</em> the experience was like a lot of horror movies rolled into one.</p> \\n<p>“The smoke, the heat, the sparks and the unknowing, but yet in the back of your mind, there's a glimmer of hope going 'oh, this will be alright in the morning’.</p> \\n<p>“But it's not.”</p> \\n<p>The Facebook post said the family’s “home & business and a lifetime of memories are gone apart from the clothes on our backs”.</p> \\n<p>“Sleep escapes me and I can’t get rid of the taste of smoke from my mouth or close my eyes without seeing a monstrous orange maelstrom roaring towards us.”</p> \\n<p>The post thanked friends, the community and guests from across the world for their messages of support.</p> \\n<p>Spiers said he was trying to keep a positive attitude after the blaze.</p> \\n<p>“Where's my glasses, where's my watch, where's my wallet, it's all burnt,\\\" he said.</p> \\n<p>“You can't buy undies in Twizel ... you can buy socks, but you can't buy undies.”</p> \\n<h3>Help for residents</h3> \\n<p>The Waitaki Emergency Operations Centre was working with those affected by the fire to ascertain their needs over the coming days and weeks.</p> \\n<p>Three busloads of property owners were taken see the damage for themselves on Monday afternoon, while residents who needed to retrieve essential items from undamaged properties would be able to register to be escorted to and from their homes from Tuesday.</p> \\n<p>The managed access would be for urgent essential purposes, such as tradespeople retrieving tools or people needing medication.</p> \\n<p>The access would be available between 10am and 2pm provided conditions are safe for entry, Hands said. Residents will be transported in and out in a Fire and Emergency vehicle.</p> \\n<p>\\\"We appreciate how anxious people are to return home, or to retrieve personal possessions. We are providing escorted access as an interim step,” Hands said.</p> \\n<p>Affected residents were being provided with meal vouchers, access to emergency medication and everyone was given accommodation on Sunday night.</p> \\n<p>Incident controller Murray Linwood praised those affected for their evacuation effort.</p> \\n<p>He also thanked the Mackenzie and Waitaki communities for their offers of support.</p> \\n<h3>Coastguard support</h3> \\n<p>About 10 Coastguard volunteers from Tekapo and Twizel spent a gruelling 12 hours on the wind-ravaged Lake Ōhau on Sunday, with the same numbers returning to the water at first light on Monday to continue supporting helicopters fighting the blaze.</p> \\n<p>Coastguard Southern regional manager Cheryl Moffat said they were looking at bringing in a relief crew from other parts of the South Island to take over the two boats on the lake watching over helicopter pilots.</p> \\n<p>\\\"It's pretty hard on the volunteers, because the wind is strong and the lake is very rough,’’ she said.</p> \\n<p>The wind had caused waves of up to 4 metres in some parts of the lake.</p> \\n<p>\\\"They're happy to do it to help the community. But they've been out there two days, and potentially we'll need to be out there for another day. We need to think about their health.\\\"</p> \\n<h3>CAUSE OF FIRE NOT YET KNOWN</h3> \\n<p>Network Waitaki chief executive Geoff Douch said the lines company had been \\\"flat out\\\" trying to help Ōhau locals and work with Fenz and other agencies involved.</p> \\n<p>\\\"Any speculation on the cause [of the fire] is just that, speculation. We are working hard helping Fenz in their investigations,\\\" he said.</p>\",\"stuffNationAssignment\":false,\"stuffNationAssignmentId\":null,\"stuffNationContribution\":false,\"allowComments\":false,\"adExclusions\":[],\"brandsAndCategories\":[{\"categories\":[{\"category\":\"nz/national\"},{\"category\":\"nz/the-press/canterbury-top-stories\"},{\"category\":\"nz/timaru-herald/news\"},{\"category\":\"nz/authors/steven-walton\"},{\"category\":\"nz/stuff-homepage\"},{\"category\":\"nz/timaru-herald/timaru-top-stories\"},{\"category\":\"nz/the-press/news\"}]}],\"findStuffNationAssignmentArticlesById\":{\"queryResults\":[]},\"sources\":[{\"source\":\"Stuff\"}],\"getSource\":{\"jcrTitle\":\"Stuff\"},\"keywords\":[\"Civil href=\\\"https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/122975420/high-winds-to-remain-a-problem-in-devastating-lake-ohau-firefight?rm=a\\\">High winds to remain a problem in devastating Lake Ohau firefight</a><br> </strong>\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Earlier on Monday, Fenz incident controller Graeme Still told media on a tour of the Lake Ōhau Village that the fire was the biggest in terms of destruction in his 40 years of firefighting.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Fenz Te Kei region manager Mike Grant said it had been a huge firefighting effort.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"You have to be really on the button,'' he said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" He said gullies around the hills acted like a chimney, which meant there was very little fire suppression.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"When we get into areas where the standing trees are, we're talking 50, 80, 100 tonne per hectare, what that does is increases the intensity of fire and makes it more difficult to suppress.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Still earlier revealed the fight against the blaze was going well.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"The fire is what we call contained, and we're on top of it, but never say never with these winds.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The media bus tour followed an announcement that the Government would provide $100,000 as an initial contribution to help those affected by the fire.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Civil Defence Minister Peeni Henare announced the fund as he offered his thoughts to residents.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"What we've just witnessed is completely devastating for the people of this community,'' he said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"All of the feedback we've had from Fenz is that this is a significant event.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"We will work closely with the mayor here and the Waitaki District Council on an ongoing basis and will assess their need and step in and support where we can.\\\"\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Conservation Minister Eugenie Sage acknowledged the \\\"devastating loss\\\" for residents and those who had homes in Lake Ōhau.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" She described seeing cars “with melted tyres, bunk bed frames and houses completely gone”.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" About 1800ha of conservation land had been affected by the fire.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" She said land management \\\"had to be looked at\\\" given the changing climate.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “We need to be fire smart in the future.\\\"\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Waitaki District mayor Gary Kircher described the event as “absolutely devastating” for the community, but said a lot of people were already talking about rebuilding. \"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" It was a “minor miracle” no-one was harmed.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “The reality is that another 15 or 20 minutes could've been a very different story.\\\"\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Kircher had already heard several stories of heroism, including a man who woke up to his dog about 3am on Sunday.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “He went out opened the door and just saw a wall of orange coming towards the village, he shot down and turned on the village alarm and that helped get a lot of people out of bed and then the residents went door to door making sure that everyone was aware and able to get out.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"Actions like that which have helped save lives.\\\"\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Kircher said the community’s response showed some “pretty good presence of thought”.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “It's a testament to the plan the community had for such an event ... they were well-prepared, they've done their practices.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\"  Graham Smith, mayor of the neighbouring Mackenzie district, said the Twizel community's support for homeowners affected by the fire was \\\"absolutely wonderful\\\".\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"Over 100 people ended up staying in Twizel from Lake Ōhau village overnight.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"This fire is in Waitaki's patch, but it's a much larger fire than <a href=\\\"http://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/300095062/aorakimt-cook-evacuated-in-the-face-of-massive-mackenzie-district-scrubfire\\\">the one in Pukaki</a> a few weeks ago. That one stretched about 300ha, this one has spread about 1600ha.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Smith said some farmers had lost stock, and many homes were destroyed.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"It's a huge loss,\\\" he said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" MetService spokeswoman Melissa Oosterwijk said gusts in the area overnight Sunday reached 60kmh to 65kmh and there was no rainfall.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" MetService <a href=\\\"https://twitter.com/MetService/status/1312498027429466115?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet\\\">issued a strong wind warning for the Canterbury High Country</a> from 10am Monday to 9am Tuesday.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" At 6.40am, nearby Lake Pukaki was already at 16 degrees Celsius.\"},{\"name\":\"h3\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" ‘Monstrous orange maelstrom’\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Those behind a Lake Ōhau bed and breakfast business confirmed <a href=\\\"https://www.facebook.com/TheBarnBB/posts/1455406441326427\\\">in a Facebook post</a> on Monday that they had lost their home.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The Barn at Killin said the family running the business was safe and were being looked after by friends.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Owner Hugh Spiers told <em>Stuff</em> the experience was like a lot of horror movies rolled into one.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “The smoke, the heat, the sparks and the unknowing, but yet in the back of your mind, there's a glimmer of hope going 'oh, this will be alright in the morning’.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “But it's not.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The Facebook post said the family’s “home & business and a lifetime of memories are gone apart from the clothes on our backs”.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “Sleep escapes me and I can’t get rid of the taste of smoke from my mouth or close my eyes without seeing a monstrous orange maelstrom roaring towards us.”\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The post thanked friends, the community and guests from across the world for their messages of support.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Spiers said he was trying to keep a positive attitude after the blaze.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “Where's my glasses, where's my watch, where's my wallet, it's all burnt,\\\" he said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" “You can't buy undies in Twizel ... you can buy socks, but you can't buy undies.”\"},{\"name\":\"h3\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Help for residents\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The Waitaki Emergency Operations Centre was working with those affected by the fire to ascertain their needs over the coming days and weeks.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Three busloads of property owners were taken see the damage for themselves on Monday afternoon, while residents who needed to retrieve essential items from undamaged properties would be able to register to be escorted to and from their homes from Tuesday.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The managed access would be for urgent essential purposes, such as tradespeople retrieving tools or people needing medication.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The access would be available between 10am and 2pm provided conditions are safe for entry, Hands said. Residents will be transported in and out in a Fire and Emergency vehicle.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"We appreciate how anxious people are to return home, or to retrieve personal possessions. We are providing escorted access as an interim step,” Hands said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Affected residents were being provided with meal vouchers, access to emergency medication and everyone was given accommodation on Sunday night.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Incident controller Murray Linwood praised those affected for their evacuation effort.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" He also thanked the Mackenzie and Waitaki communities for their offers of support.\"},{\"name\":\"h3\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Coastguard support\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" About 10 Coastguard volunteers from Tekapo and Twizel spent a gruelling 12 hours on the wind-ravaged Lake Ōhau on Sunday, with the same numbers returning to the water at first light on Monday to continue supporting helicopters fighting the blaze.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Coastguard Southern regional manager Cheryl Moffat said they were looking at bringing in a relief crew from other parts of the South Island to take over the two boats on the lake watching over helicopter pilots.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"It's pretty hard on the volunteers, because the wind is strong and the lake is very rough,’’ she said.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" The wind had caused waves of up to 4 metres in some parts of the lake.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"They're happy to do it to help the community. But they've been out there two days, and potentially we'll need to be out there for another day. We need to think about their health.\\\"\"},{\"name\":\"h3\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" CAUSE OF FIRE NOT YET KNOWN\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" Network Waitaki chief executive Geoff Douch said the lines company had been \\\"flat out\\\" trying to help Ōhau locals and work with Fenz and other agencies involved.\"},{\"name\":\"p\",\"attributes\":{},\"content\":\" \\\"Any speculation on the cause [of the fire] is just that, speculation. We are working hard helping Fenz in their investigations,\\\" he said.\"}],\"layouts\":[],\"displayFlags\":[\"VIDEO\"],\"section\":\"nz/national\",\"display_assets\":[{\"type\":\"RelatedVideo\",\"assetId\":\"122977958\",\"suppressPrerolls\":false,\"headline\":\"Devastation in Lake Ōhau Village\",\"indexIntroText\":\"Exclusive Stuff on the ground footage of the fire ravaged buildings in Lake Ōhau village.\",\"producer\":\"Charlie       <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">We’d like to ask for your help. In a fast-changing world where misinformation spreads on social media, the need for trustworthy journalism has never been greater. But the media industry faces strong headwinds. Traditional means of funding journalism - such as advertising and subscriptions to our newspapers - have declined, compounded by the economic impact of Covid-19.</p>\\n        <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">We’re asking our readers to help us continue to play our vital role in society. Stuff holds a special position in New Zealand, with the largest network of newsrooms - hundreds of journalists from Northland to Southland. We’re part of your local community, doggedly pursuing the issues that matter.</p>\\n        <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">We hold the powerful to account - from making sure your rates are spent wisely to challenging Cabinet ministers who flout the rules.</p>\\n        <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">We uncover hidden truths - from the Defence Force’s activities in Afghanistan to which companies commit the greatest climate damage.</p>\\n        <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">And we champion Kiwi communities and values - from fighting for New Zealand history to be taught in schools to enhancing coverage of Te Ao Māori with our new Pou Tiaki section.</p>\\n        <p class=\\\"support-brief-container-text\\\">In an age where rumours and speculation spread unchecked on social media, Stuff’s professional standards of accuracy, fairness and balance are more vital than ever. <b>Please consider becoming a supporter.
