summary:
Exclusive Stuff on the ground footage of the fire ravaged buildings in Lake Ōhau village.
Firefighters will work through the night to deal with any flare-ups after a massive fire at Lake Ōhau ripped through 5360 hectares and damaged 46 homes.
Conservation Minister Eugenie Sage acknowledged the "devastating loss" for residents and those who had homes in Lake Ōhau.
CHARLIE O'MANNIN/Stuff Damage in the Lake Ōhau village after the fire.
Breakfast A large blaze ripped through Lake Ohau Village in the Waitaki District destroying many homes.
title: Lake Ōhau fire destroys over 5000ha and leaves 46 homes uninhabitable

text:
Over the last few years, longtime surfer/shaper and longboard star CJ Nelson had an awakening of sorts — one that had a profound impact on him personally and trickled down to affect his business, his craft, his surfing… pretty much every facet of his life. For the better. He’d stopped competing, his company had maxed out, and his designs required a fresh, clean incubator to go to the next level. Fast-forward to a brand-new decade, and Firewire has become the global distributor for CJ Nelson Designs, all of which are still hand-built, one at a time, by CJ and his trusty team. Upon tackling that transition, everything else has fallen into place. Wanna know his secret?

“Get motivated and inspired!” says CJ. “Get off your phone or computer and get outside in the sun and water. Let the bullshit go! Life is passing us by as we fish Instagram for the next meaningless ‘like’ from a stranger, or the next stupid comment war we can sink our egos into. This whole thing is and will always be about surfing. And surfing is a dance you do alone. Don’t give one singular second of it away.”

An earful like that certainly deserves another, so Surfline hit up CJ to hear more.

Surfline: Firewire is now distributing your designs to more surf retailers. When did you decide to take your designs to Firewire, and which individuals were instrumental in that shift?

CJ Nelson: In late 2017, CJ Nelson Designs hit its ceiling. We were maxed out, we needed better account servicing, and we just didn’t have the reach we needed for the demand we were getting. We took a trip to Hawaii around that time and brainstormed our best-case scenarios for breaking free and finding the help we needed. Firewire was at the top of that list. We knew they’d never been a distributor for boards other than their own, but we felt it could still work out. My partner Mark Nelson took the reins on reaching out and was warmly welcomed. We went into a series of meetings for the better part of 2018 and were able to come to a mutually beneficial agreement. It took a lot of people to get it all together but Mark Nelson and Mark Price were the most instrumental in making it happen. Mark Nelson has done more for me and my personal growth than anyone in my life. He’s truly one of the greatest men I’ve ever met. I am forever grateful.

What does the partnership entail exactly, and how involved are you in the design process?

We laugh about this a lot, because it’s complicated and viewed differently by all involved. The simplest way of putting it is Firewire is the Global Distributor of my brand. That being said, there’s so much that comes along with that, the statement doesn’t credit Firewire enough. All of the changes were mostly administrative, and there were lots. However, our building process didn’t change at all. Yu Sumitomo, Wayne Rich, Eden Saul, Ian Chisholm and Ryan Engle are all still running point. All our boards are built by hand, one at a time. I do 100% of the design — from conception to testing, finishes, weights and color ways. The design process takes a mountain of effort, but it’s incredibly rewarding.

Were there any specific challenges? Did this ever feel like uncharted territory?

I thought it was going to feel like uncharted territory, like it’d be a corporate vibe, and I was super wrong. Everyone I work with is cool as f**k. The guys at Firewire are just normal guys who surf and pick their nose, like me. They just work really hard and they’re smart. The challenges were never social, because I instantly loved everyone there, but purely on the building end of things. We’re building more boards than ever before with zero room for mistakes. It takes a special group of craftsmen to rise to that challenge and be accountable for their shortcomings. I can honestly say that it’s brought out the best of everyone involved. It’s been beautiful to watch.

Where does this new relationship with Firewire fit in with your major goals and timeline — both in terms of your business model as well as your personal aesthetic?

When I started, my goal was to build the best, easiest-riding, most beautiful surfboard in the world with the people I love the most. Then my goal became to get them in as many hands as possible so that people could appreciate them. I’ve been able to execute this well, and we’re really just getting started. When I went into business, I was equally interested in the business side of things as the artistic and creative side of things. I never wanted another hobby, I wanted to enjoy the hobbies I have, surfing being #1. I wanted a successful business that would complement my lifestyle, rather than take from my lifestyle. I feel like I’ve achieved my goals without any aesthetic or moral compromise. In fact, Firewire is helping me fulfill one of my final goals — getting our shapes Eco Board Certified — which has been a big one for me since the beginning.

Given your lengthy background as a multi-generational, if not era-defining surfer/designer, where are you at right now in terms of your craft, your business, and your surfing?

Things are really great at the moment. I’m genuinely happy and grateful every day. I’m at a place where I just ride what feels best without looking too much into trends or history. Those things can confine you to directions that may not be that functional. I’m just interested in designs that are built around feel. If it’s not feeling incredible underfoot, it’s just a fashion accessory, which becomes a ball and chain that halts a person’s progression. It’s nice to honor the past, but I’m more interested in the now and the future. New designs and materials keep me inspired. And business has been fantastic. It’s a constant learning experience and definitely has its ups and downs, but it’s incredibly interesting and rewarding. Growing up in shaping rooms and factories, I had a good opportunity as a kid to see what works and what doesn’t — what generally makes boardbuilders so miserable and why. It took me a long time to understand how the people building the best things on Earth could be so salty and bitter. Learning how to navigate the surfboard business without developing those personality traits is important to me. Luckily, one of my best friends since childhood, Yu Sumitomo, is my partner and he’s arguably one of the best boardbuilders in the world. He’s got this shit down and has taught me so much about happiness and priorities. If you’re not happy every day, then what’s the point? Do something else. I surround myself with art and design, and positive and inspired people who are great at their jobs.

And…?

And I surf. A lot. Surfing is the most important thing to me. I know it sounds cliché, but it’s been the constant thing that’s kept me on the right track in life. With so many talented and professional people involved in my business now, I’m able to surf more than ever. I pretty much surf and film every day and review the footage closely. I scrutinize my hands, arms and foot placement. I’m continually trying to correct my dance and perfect the way the boards are working. There is a certain way I’ve always wanted to surf, and I’m just now achieving that goal. The feeling you get from the connectivity of your craft to water is very personal, so you better be real with yourself. If it doesn’t feel great, then trash it. I surf exactly the way I want, on what I want, with no exceptions.

Are you inspired, shocked or indifferent about the current zeitgeist of longboarders shaping and riding their own equipment, both in and out of Duct Tape competition?

I love the kids. I think it’s awesome that some of them are taking the initiative to build their own boards and learn the craft. With the ongoing state of longboard surfing, really the only way to make it is to hustle. I do, however, think that it’s important to try and ride everything, so you don’t get sucked into the vortex of which design is coolest on Instagram. I think it’s important for every aspiring great surfer to build their own stuff, but also partner with a reputable shaper who can guide you and put a ton of great boards under you.

As a Duct Tape O.G., what can you say about the whole DIY ethos of the Duct Tape crew?

I think its cool to see the DIY nature of these kids, but in the same breath, it’s kinda sad. Most DIY situations are born out of necessity, and this situation is no different. The surf industry has overlooked longboard culture for so long that everyone lost hope. These kids aren’t stupid. Most shops don’t want ‘em, so they open their own. Clothing companies don’t want ‘em, so they make their own. Board companies don’t want ‘em, so they shape their own. Surf contests don’t want ‘em, so they have their own… It’s awesome, but bittersweet too. It’s incredible to see the success of the Duct Tape series that Joel Tudor and Vans have done — it’s kept air in the lungs of a dying culture. I’m forever grateful for my opportunities there, and the new opportunities it’s creating for these kids. In longboarding’s greatest time of need, Joel and Vans stepped up and put things on track. God bless ‘em.

Anything else you care to add?

Get motivated and inspired! Get off your phone or computer and get outside in the sun and water. Let the bullshit go! Life is passing us by as we fish Instagram for the next meaningless ‘like’ from a stranger or the next stupid comment war we can sink our egos into. This whole thing is (and will always be) about the surfing – and surfing is a dance you do alone…don’t give one singular second of it away.

Thanks for the opportunity to share. Thank you to all the people that ride our boards. I appreciate you.

text:
John 'Badger' McBride sits on Craig Sutcliffe's 1600cc German built Boom Trike at the start of the GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally from Timaru on Saturday.

Motorcyclists tested their observation and map skills during the 28th GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally.

Twenty-four novice and experienced riders took part in the Timaru Bronz (Bikers Rights Organisation of New Zealand) organised rally where motorcyclists followed instructions over 160kms to the mystery destination of the Glenavy River Motor Camp on Saturday

Rally founder/organiser and Timaru Bronz member Morris Jones said participants came from as far afield as Christchurch and Gore to take part in the rally.

“The conditions were good as the riders embarked on the mystery run, the course taking them through the Taiko Valley and Pareora Gorge, then via Otaio to the lunch stop at the Makikihi Country Hotel.”

READ MORE:

* Timaru GlobeTrotter motorcycle rally all about the mystery



As part of the event, riders had to count the green banded road marker posts along Davison Rd, call into the Cave Store to pick up a playing card, identify a wind indicator and its colour as well as an old derelict Bedford truck parked up in a paddock.

Another set of instructions after lunch guided riders along coastal roads, then inland at Morven to travel through Waikakahi Valley to Glenavy.

Bejon Haswell/Stuff Riders took off in staged intervals in the rally.

Then it was time for games including a helmet throwing competition and tug-of-war before a meal and prize giving. Riders stayed overnight, returning home on Sunday.

Points were gained, or lost, over the rally including for incorrect kilometres travelled, inaccurate answers, arriving at the final checkpoint either too early or late, and correct answers.

Bejon Haswell/Stuff GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally founder and organiser Morris Jones debriefs riders at the start on Saturday.

Prize winners were:

First overall: Jason Jones, second overall: Phil Drake, third overall: Angela Languish

Bejon Haswell/Stuff Twenty-four motorcyclists leave Timaru Yamaha in Washdyke for the GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally.

First team home: Team Misfits – Jason McLauglin, George Stephens and Dougal Lamont, of Ashburton

First Timaru Bronz club member: Dougal Lamont.

Helmet Throwing: Mens - Phil Drake Womens - Angela Languish.

Tug-of-War: Team Allan – Allan Charles, Malcolm Baird, Glen Hay, of Christchurch

News

GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally a hit across 160km in South Canterbury

Esther Ashby-Coventry12:11, Oct 05 2020
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Whats App
  • Reddit
  • Email

Motorcyclists tested their observation and map skills during the 28th GlobeTrotter Challenge Rally.

Twenty-four novice and experienced riders took part in the Timaru Bronz (Bikers Rights Organisation of New Zealand) organised rally where motorcyclists followed instructions over 160kms to the mystery destination of the Glenavy River Motor Camp on Saturday

Rally founder/organiser and Timaru Bronz member Morris Jones said participants came from as far afield as Christchurch and Gore to take part in the rally.

“The conditions were good as the riders embarked on the mystery run, the course taking them through the Taiko Valley and Pareora Gorge, then via Otaio to the lunch stop at the Makikihi Country Hotel.”

READ MORE:
* Timaru GlobeTrotter motorcycle rally all about the mystery

As part of the event, riders had to count the green banded road marker posts along Davison Rd, call into the Cave Store to pick up a playing card, identify a wind indicator and its colour as well as an old derelict Bedford truck parked up in a paddock.

Another set of instructions after lunch guided riders along coastal roads, then inland at Morven to travel through Waikakahi Valley to Glenavy.

Then it was time for games including a helmet throwing competition and tug-of-war before a meal and prize giving. Riders stayed overnight, returning home on Sunday.

Points were gained, or lost, over the rally including for incorrect kilometres travelled, inaccurate answers, arriving at the final checkpoint either too early or late, and correct answers.

Prize winners were:

First overall: Jason Jones, second overall: Phil Drake, third overall: Angela Languish

First team home: Team Misfits – Jason McLauglin, George Stephens and Dougal Lamont, of Ashburton

First Timaru Bronz club member: Dougal Lamont.

Helmet Throwing: Mens - Phil Drake Womens - Angela Languish.

Tug-of-War: Team Allan – Allan Charles, Malcolm Baird, Glen Hay, of Christchurch
